title: the sun reader letters boris burka
story: But there has been a groundswell of support for BoJo from ordinary people, fed up at what they see as attacks on freedom of expression and the British way of life.This is what Sun readers have to say about the issue, and Brexit-backer Boris:BORIS Johnson has a dig at burka-wearing Muslims and our elite shake with fear. Don’t they know many thousands of people agree with him? Or do they chose to again ignore the people of this country? Any movement on Boris from the out-of-touch Government will cost them dear.SO Dominic Grieve has threatened to quit Parliament if Boris Johnson became PM. I can think of no better reason for wishing him success.BANG on Boris, about the burka. It being worn in public is scary for children who see it.FREEDOM of speech must not be compromised – and there can be no question of legal action being taken against Boris Johnson, it would be prejudiced by all the attacks on him.THIS week it has been especially hard to be a Muslim woman. Apparently I am not getting the joke, I’m over sensitive, bullied, oppressed, unintegrated, politically motivated, dividing Britain – this list goes on. Perhaps Boris Johnson’s Etonian education did not enable him to understand that in polite society it’s rude to comment with ridicule on the way people dress.ONE thing critics of Boris Johnson’s burka comment overlook is the impact of burka-wearers on those who are deaf and rely on seeing facial expressions, and lip-reading.THE do-gooders complaining about Boris are fanning the flames of hatred by highlighting issues that one wouldn’t really think about. Talk about “integration” appears to be one-sided and discriminatory towards the indigenous people. There is some equilibrium lacking in our “fair, just and equal” land of ours.WHILE I am not sure Boris used a good choice of words likening women in burkas to pillar boxes, he was right that we are frightened by what it represents. We must not destroy Boris, he is good for the people of this country, he cares. He must also be allowed to speak honestly, he has nothing to apologise for.LIGHTEN up, Boris spoke the thoughts of many millions of Brits. If making a gaffe was against the law, Prince Philip could have been banged up in the Tower of London on many occasions during the last 50 years. He wrote the book on it.Boris might have an agenda – what politician doesn’t? – but this mustn’t mean people don’t have a right to voice criticism. Face veils in public, and burkas, are not religious requirements and we must have the right to criticise the wearers.IF I was Boris Johnson, I would agree to attend the diversity training some have suggested . . . and then tear the training session to pieces.I SAW Ranvir Singh berating her guests on morning TV for daring to agree with Boris Johnson? I wonder what her bosses would say if she suggested that she presented her programme wearing a burka. I think we all know the answer to that.PHIL GROWDENNOTHING Theresa May says can be taken at face value. Not so long ago, she promised to stop the witch-hunt of British soldiers, who have seen action and survived in many parts of the world. However, the victimisation of our veterans continues unabated. They are now joined by Boris Johnson, who has frequently ignited the Prime Minister’s wrath and must therefore, be thrown to the wolves.A BUS company has apologised after a driver told a woman to remove her niqab. So would a bank apologise if a security guard asked a man to remove his ski mask?HOW would I stand as a Christian male finding a Muslim lady, dressed in a burka, having a heart attack? Would I be allowed to remove her veil to perform mouth-to-mouth?THE controversy surrounding Boris Johnson’s burka comments has reached ridiculous heights. Police conducting an investigation. Really?IF Theresa May had the guts to ban the burka like a lot of other countries, we might not be having this discussion about what Boris Johnson said.SOMETHING featureless with a rectangular hole in it can resemble a letter box, there’s probably one on your front door, go and have a look. It has also been known for the person inside to be a terrorist, not an innocent woman. Stop being so pathetic, have a sense of humour, act like adultsI READ about a motorcyclist at a filling station having to remove his crash helmet while a woman (who could have been a criminal’s getaway driver) filling up at the pump next to him was wearing a burka. Meanwhile Boris’s remarks are causing hysteria.I HAVE been visiting garden centres and supermarket car parks in my car, which is bedecked with Brexit stickers, asking many people their opinion on the Boris situation. For Boris, I find there is a great deal of love out there. For the Chequers “deal” there is none.IT’S true that Boris Johnson has used strong language but Muslim terrorists are doing far worse things than robbing banks, by committing terrorist atrocities. It would be a sad day when the Muslim community can’t take such a comment, especially when many Muslim women, in my view, do not want this clothing themselves.IT’S confirmed, lunatics are ruining the country. We have the enemy (EU) knocking art the door and all the idiots can find to discuss is Boris Johnson’s perfectly fair comment. If it wasn’t so serious it would be funny. Brexit should be top of the agenda.THERE are easily as many people who agree with BoJo’s comments as those who don’t. So why is it those who don’t will instigate an investigation, leaving those who do without a voice? Even senior Muslims and imams have said that the burka is not a requirement in Islam, so why is it we only tend to listen to those who are offended?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the last leg ally ross
story: You expect this reaction, obviously, from news organisations who have to fill endless blank hours with something during silly season.The really depressing thing, though, was that a late-night Channel 4 “comedy” show and its presenters were the most outraged of them all.I’m talking, of course, about The Last Leg which, for reasons that still escape me, genuinely fancies itself as one of television’s edgiest and funniest shows.It’s not, clearly. The Last Leg is a television safe space, the authentic voice of the PC establishment and as predictable as the sun rising in the morning.So you knew, long before Friday’s transmission, that they’d be targeting Boris, who is a thousand times funnier and edgier than anyone on this show, in his own way.Nearly a whole working week host Adam Hills and his two mates had to prepare some decent material as well, and this was the best three professional comedians could do.Alex Brooker: “The burka is an item of clothing worn by a human being, the other is a postbox, you f***ing idiot.”Adam Hills: “I’d much rather sit next to a person in burka than a p***k in a suit.”Josh Widdicombe: “Theresa May has only just realised Boris is a t**t, so she should apologise as well.”On and on it went, for 12 minutes and 54 seconds, a figure I mention because I’ve had the clock on this lot, and if you want to know exactly how much of a toss they really give about religious sensitivities then it’s best measured by the fact this series of The Last Leg has devoted just 65 hand-wringing seconds to the anti-Semitic poison infecting the Labour Party.It was crammed hurriedly into the previous episode, which was worth watching just to see Adam Hills describe Corbyn’s handling of this crisis as “a faux pas”, (which isn’t French for “shameful cluster-f***”) and the C4 audience react with evident discomfort because he’d drawn attention to the Labour leader’s failings and, therefore, broken one of comedy’s secret and golden rules.If you doubted these rules exist, incidentally, then ever the virtue-signalling fool, Adam Hills was good enough to spell them out for us on Friday.“Every religion should be open to ridicule . . . but you kind of need to be in the club.“Alex and I can make jokes about disabilities as we’re technically disabled.”Boris, he then explained, can’t make jokes about burkas, ’cos he’s “a white Etonian”, nor could comedy giant Rowan Atkinson defend him, as he was “a white man who lives in Oxford and drives an F1 car”.Even if we ignore the fact he’s assumed that all Muslims are black, something pretty staggering is going on here.For Mary Whitehouse, in all her pearl-clutching glory, never imagined anything quite as Draconian and controlling as this form of satirical Apartheid.Adam Hills has a point, though, when he uses the word “club”. That’s exactly what television comedy has become.A closed, left-wing shop where you don’t even bother joining the audience unless you follow the rigid “Tories and Brexit are evil” party line.This is not creating comedy, it’s policing it, and also the reason why applause has replaced laughter on all those Channel 4 and BBC news satires which have failed to realise there is only one simple rule to be observed when creating these shows: Make it funny, dumbo.I would suggest, at this point, Adam Hills gets off his moral high horse, for once, and gives this “funny” idea a go.But then I could also ask Boris to have a crack at anchoring the British women’s 4x100m relay team to gold at the next Olympics, wearing a burka, and I’d know there was only the remotest chance of one ever happening.Run Boris, run.MEANWHILE, back on Channel 4’s Meet The Drug Lords: Inside The Real Narcos, Jason “Foxy” Fox was with the Colombian navy this week and desperate for a look inside one of the incredible home-made submarines they’d confiscated from drug-smugglers.“Is it locked?”“Yes.”And there’ll be more Bafta-worthy action from Foxy and his forward-planning department this week, I’m sure.EVER since it discovered that Danny Dyer was the rightful heir to the English throne, Who Do You Think You Are? has been struggling to find a purpose, or indeed a celebrity, who could see the bigger picture.That special someone who would acknowledge history’s great events with more than a few “wows” and shrugs and not think their own career made all of their ancestors’ suffering worthwhile.Finally, last night, they found him.Judge Robert Rinder, who as well as having the best brain at ITV (Luna the Labrador off This Morning has the second best) also turns out to be a natural television journalist, telling the story of his maternal great-grandfather, Israel, and his beloved grandfather, Morris, simply, beautifully and without ever letting the details overwhelm him.The former fled revolutionary Latvia at the turn of the last century.The latter’s entire family was wiped out in Treblinka’s gas chambers.Yet he somehow survived the Buchen-wald, Theresienstadt and Schlieben concentration camps and made it to Britain, which offered him salvation, friendship, justice and, above all, a sense that “life is worth living” that has been passed down through eternally grateful generations.It’s a remarkable story, so if you missed it, try to catch tonight’s repeat (BBC1, 11.25pm).SCENES and characters the viewers are unlikely to forget in a hurry on the final episode of BBC2’s wonderful Travels In Trumpland With Ed Balls.First stop, the President’s Mar-a-Lago compound in Florida, where Ed spent the most uncomfortable night of his life, since Strictly, at a one-year-in-office party for Trump, with Toni Holt Kramer and a group of fans who were called The Trumpettes, but could well have been the provisional wing of The Golden Girls.If you thought they were a bit sinister, though, he was then off squirrel hunting in the forests of Georgia with two hillbillies who might not have been plucking banjos but they certainly had the mad cackling laughs and slightly unsettling line in hospitality.“Are you ready to be a man today, Ed?” asked one, as you began to wonder if he could escape with his dignity intact, let alone blend in with the local gene pool.Then he suddenly reappeared – and this was a masterstroke – wearing a Norwich City scarf.Scrub everything I ever said about Ed Balls.The man’s a diplomatic genius.Sent in by Rob Milner, East Yorkshire. Right now I’m ambivalent abOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: first part time jobs sun writers
story: The number of 16 to 17-year-olds taking part-time jobs has more than halved since 1997, dropping from 42 per cent to 18 per cent. It means young people are missing out on essential skills as they approach adulthood.GRANT ROLLINGS asked five Sun columnists what their first part-time jobs were and the valuable lessons they learned – from being polite to skiving.I ALWAYS had a summer job, usually it meant working full-time hours on my normal Saturday job as holiday cover. This was either in a boutique such as Chelsea Girl or in BHS, where I worked on the sweetie counter.I coped with the boredom by sneakily munching on the best chocolate sweets from the pick-and-mix. I also worked as a waitress in a trendy Glasgow eaterie during the holidays.All of these jobs gave me the most enormous respect for the men and women who toil for long hours, often dealing with unreasonable members of the public for too little pay and not much prospect of promotion.Working in the service industry taught me the power of a disarming smile, and proved that my old granny’s saying that “you get more in life from sugar than vinegar” could not be more true.Grumpy customers demanding refunds and diners moaning that they had been waiting too long for their main course were usually placated with a swift apology and a promise to sort things out.A major restaurant blunder could often be smoothed over with a free coffee or pudding.MY favourite summer job came in 1977. I was a traffic enumerator for Middlesbrough Council. That meant I spent all day counting cars. All the way up one side of Linthorpe Road, all the way back down the other.I had to write down all the number plates. In the end, I got a bit bored and spent the time hanging out at my mate’s T-shirt shop or Fearnley Records and made the numbers up, always remembering to have them end in the local codes of HN or (I think) XG. I hope the council thought it worthwhile.It was better than the glue factory, where I’d been very briefly working on a weighbridge. Foreman pressed a button and this vast door opened and thousands of rotting animal carcasses fell out. I can still smell it now, all these years later. I passed out — soft lad, you see.Or there was working the nightshift pricing cans of food and stuff in Hintons, the local convenience store. Every time I turned up, the manager would say, ‘Here he is, the poor man’s Rod Stewart’.A friend of mine, Mark, had a much better summer job.He was a Club 18-30 holiday rep. He shagged 21 girls in 25 days, which gave me my first story to sell to the national newspapers.MY first holiday job was in the summer of 1985 when I was 16 years old. I had already been turned down from working at Waitrose in Enfield Town on the basis I was “too glamorous”.That just goes to show how far we have come in such a short time. I have never set foot in a Waitrose since that day because I was beyond furious. Anyway, the job I did get was working in a hairdresser’s on Goodge Street in London.My journey involved three changes and about 14 stops every day. The job was meant to be answering the phone, sweeping up and generally helping out, but before the end of the first week I was running the till, the appointment system, cashing up and generally managing the place.The only thing I could not do was cut hair, but that didn’t stop me cutting my friends’ hair — with very mixed results, more bad than good — on the basis I worked in a hairdresser’s so they thought I should. I remember the liberating feeling of earning my own money, it gave me the greatest sense of independence, self-esteem and self-belief.I worked out I was actually good in a work environment, talking to people — for example, talking women into perms they didn’t want — being responsible, handling money and making a difference to my employer.The biggest transition we make in our lives is leaving education to go into the workplace, and summer jobs prepare you for this.I HAD dozens of summer jobs, from working as a scaffolder’s mate with a convicted murderer, who kept a pistol in the glove compartment of his Ford Escort, to donning a white suit and Geiger counter to carry out maintenance on the core of the main reactor at a nuclear power station.I learned a hundred things from each and every job, but it was working as a grocery assistant at my local supermarket that had the most impact.My best friend and I both got jobs there at the same time. He was a star performer at school, a brilliant academic, but he couldn’t take the pace and got fired after a couple of months.It was incredibly hard, repetitive work.The manager was an ex-Army major — very strict on haircuts, discipline and stealing.There was always the prospect of the Tannoy announcement “customer service one hundred”, which was code for a shoplifter having been spotted.All the male floor staff were required to assemble at till number one to tackle the suspect, who would sometimes become violent.I was much happier making the cheese look pretty and eventually became the ruler of the entire soft dairy aisle — a project I’m still working on.I WAS 13 in Brownes Wine bar, Stafford Street, Derby, summer 1987, some years before it burned down in mysterious circumstances (has a bar ever burnt down innocently?). I was chief bottler-up.This involved the soul-sapping exercise of sifting through bins taller than me for all the recyclable bottles from the previous night’s festivities and putting them in their correct crates. This took all morning and you ended up cut to shreds and stinking of Britvic and Schlitz.I was then asked to be the cook — this involved microwaving lasagne for drunk people. I was paid the princely sum of £3 per hour. I realised how crap this was, so one scorching Saturday I nicked the shampoo that came with my dad’s company car and took advantage of the sketchy Eighties attitude to drink-driving and washed all the customers’ cars in the car park for a fiver a pop.I literally cleaned up. It was the greatest Dragons’ Den moment I’ve ever had. I waxed on and off all day, rinsing my dad of his prized BMW product. He arrived to pick me up and I was minted. A 13-year-old with £64 in his pocket. That coveted Swatch would finally be mine.He then told me the dog had been run over, so that’s another memory ruined.Thanks for reminding me.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn is unfit to be labour leader
story: His entire political career has been spent in close company with anti- Semites, terrorist sympathisers and extremists.So it shouldn’t be a surprise that he was pictured appearing to pay his respects to Black September, the terror group which murdered 11 Israelis and one German policeman at the Munich Olympics.That’s a group that not only killed in cold blood but tortured and brutalised their victims too.It is genuinely shocking that the Leader of the Opposition is so willing to lie about it. To say that he was “present but not involved” is an insult to voters’ intelligence when photographs show him holding a wreath and gurning for a nearby camera.To allow his press office to say the widows of those murdered in Munich were being “misled” is, even among the many shameful episodes we’ve seen since he became Labour leader three hate-filled years ago, disgraceful.The most vital qualification for power in this country must be integrity. And Jeremy Corbyn has demonstrated this week that he has absolutely none of it.But for all of the shame that he brings upon Labour, it is nothing compared to the spinelessness of the party’s “moderate” MPs whose opposition to Corbyn extends not much further than wishy-washy tweets.“Present but not involved” isn’t an excuse for Corbyn but nor is it for the cowards on Labour’s backbenches.Corbyn cannot be allowed near government. But the rest of the party has lost the public’s faith too.TOMORROW, official figures are likely to suggest that train fares will go up by another 3.5 per cent in January.If you’re a commuter who has put up with delayed and cancelled trains, you’ll be wondering what you’re paying for.After a disastrous year, there is no other industry that would turn round and ask customers for even more.The failure of the Government to take responsibility, blaming unions or claiming the cash is for “investment”, is simply not good enough. It’s the same as last year’s excuse.It is time for a radical overhaul — but that does not mean nationalisation. Far from it. Our railways need MORE private sector involvement.The hybrid system we have, in which private operators rely on publicly owned tracks and have their fares regulated by government, has led us into the worst of both worlds.Transport supremo Chris Grayling needs to take on the unions once and for all. And he needs to introduce real competition on the railways, giving operators far more freedom.Commuters deserve better than finger-pointing and higher fares.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rid harry and meghan turbulent
story: Most of the time, they make the Windsors seem a happy and (almost) normal bunch — no small feat.So why oh why is the Palace spin machine making such a spectacular mess with the Markles?Anybody with half a brain could tell, from the moment Prince Harry and Meghan started dating, that her family could turn into a royal pain in the neck.You’ve got a vengeful and jealous half-sister Samantha, who despises Meghan and has been briefing against her for more than a year.She is now telling hacks that she knows Harry and Meghan’s marriage won’t last, which is charming.Then you’ve got Thomas Markle, the dad, an eccentric character who is furious at being “locked out” of his daughter’s life.Barely a day goes by without Mr Markle hurling another negative headline across the Atlantic in the direction of his new son-in-law.Mr Markle insists that, contrary to official briefings, the rift between him and his daughter continues. He says he was told that he couldn’t speak at the wedding and that Harry berated him on the phone for mishandling the Press while he was recovering from a heart attack.The official royal response to these outbursts has been, effectively, to shove their fingers in their ears and shout la-la-la (or lah-lah-lah).The snobby courtiers and hangers-on dismiss Markle père as fame-hungry.That’s not altogether wrong — he is clearly desperate, as he proved by posing for snaps with the paparazzi in the run-up to the wedding.But it’s not good enough to wish he’d just go away.Meghan is now one of the most photographed and sought-after women in the world. Her very well-paid PR flunkies should have seen these familial landmines a mile off and defused them.But they have failed.Thomas Markle is a difficult and proud man, no doubt. But that is why he should have been treated with care, not frozen out.Why did Team Windsor not find him a role and approach him long before the wedding to make sure he didn’t feel excluded.It’s hard not to feel for him.His ex, Meghan’s mother Doria, was hailed as one of the stars of the wedding.Because she’s a black woman, she invited lots of gushing commentary about the monarchy becoming more diverse and modern.Amen to that. But poor old podgy Thomas, an awkward-looking white bloke, has been shunned from his daughter’s nuptials. You can’t blame him for speaking out.The royal courtiers enjoy the adulation the monarchy receives because Prince Harry has been “brave” enough to marry a woman with a complicated background.But the Palace spin machine freaks out when it comes to confronting the reality of Meghan’s parentage.Perhaps they just find it too vulgar.Harry’s PR man is Jason Knauf, an American specialist in “crisis management” having worked for Royal Bank of Scotland. He excels at sending angry letters to journalists he feels have gone too far snooping into Harry and Meghan’s private lives.But he doesn’t seem to have a clue as to how to handle his clients’ grumpy relatives.As a result, the monarchy is facing arguably its worst crisis since the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.We are often told how brilliant the Royal Family’s PR is. Part of the new royal spin, in fact, is about how great the royals now are at spin. They have “rebranded” the monarchy for the 21st century, and so on.Look at the blizzard of positive guff accompanying Prince William, Kate, and Harry’s campaign for mental illness last year.They were, it was said, making the younger Windsors seem more touchy-feely.At the moment, however, they don’t seem sensitive enough to speak to Meghan’s suffering in-laws.That’s not what you’d call a good look.The truth is, royal press officers have long got too much credit.The British admire the Queen because she is admirable.Overall, we prefer monarchy to any other system of government. That’s just common sense. It’s nothing to do with any ingenious branding and media strategy.The public also feels that the younger royals deserve a chance.At a time when our country is consumed by Brexit and political arguments, the wedding of Harry and Meghan came as a blessed relief — something we could all celebrate.The couple both came from broken homes, and nobody cared so long as they were happy. That’s all great.   But it’s obvious that Meghan has, as one royal expert put it, “background baggage that needs unpacking”.Insiders now say the treatment of the Markle family has been a “shambles”.This is before we consider the potential PR bombshells that could erupt if and when Meghan’s ex-husband, Trevor Engelson, decides to grant some interviews.The British don’t want to see the monarchy turned into a reality TV soap, as the Markles and Windsors wage a media war with each other.It’s trashy and embarrassing.But unless the Palace can tackle Meghan’s disgruntled kin, that’s exactly what is happening.Maybe we need a changing of the royal PR guard — before it’s too late.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chain smoking toddler smokes 40 cigarettes day
story: Rapi Ananda Pamungkas’ dirty habit started when he was just two months old after picking up used butts outside his mums market stall in hill station resort of Sukabumi.However, within days the two-and-a-half-year old was hooked and he began constantly pestering passing shoppers to give him cigarettes.The adults initially found the youngsters demands endearing and plied him with fags while laughing as he lit up.But Rapi - nicknamed Rap - soon started becoming aggressive and throwing tantrums when he couldnt get his beloved meroko, the local term for cigarettes.The toddler’s mum Maryati, 35, admitted that she now has to buy two packs of cigarettes every day for the boy to stop him from going beserk.She said: My child is used to smoking while drinking coffee and eating cake.“He has been smoking every day from around two months. If I dont give him a cigarette, my child goes berserk.”Maryati said Rapi began smoking after collecting cigarette butts scattered on the road which older lads lit for him.After that, he began demanding them from his parents who run a food stall which also sells cigarettes, as well as hounding passersby for his daily fix.Maryati said that it had been difficult to ban her child from smoking because he will “cry all day” if he cant smoke.She added: “If Rapi doesnt get cigarettes he cannot sleep. He will start rampaging and crying.“Its expensive, because we have to buy them for him. He likes to do it all day. He can smoke about 40 every day.”The toddler’s dad Misbahudin, 40, said he also smokes but doesnt know why his child started the habit.He added: I cannot say no to him when he asks for a cigarette. I don’t even smoke that often. I only smoke at work.“When my son smokes he likes to have a cup of mochaccino.”The parents said they will take the toddler to see a doctor to try and kick his smoking habit.Indonesia has one of the highest numbers of smokers per population in the world and a growing problem of child smokers.Around nine per cent of the country’s under-18s smoke regularly.In 2010, a two-year-old boy named Ardi Rizal achieved notoriety after it emerged he also would smoke two packets a day, with footage showing him happily smoking cigarettes.Similar footage has also emerged from China in recent years, with one video showing a three-year-old taking several deep drags on a cigarette as if addicted.That was shortly followed by extraordinary footage of a four-year-old boy, also in China, smoking cigarettes while his grandparents laughed and watched.

title: voices schizophrenia
story: But the truth is that Kyle is no killer, the blood splattered all over his clothes was his own, and the voice telling him he was a murderer was actually in his head.Kyle had reached breaking point and slashed his own skull with a knife in a bid to drown out the voice that had been terrorising him for months.One in ten people regularly hear voices that others dont as a result of illnesses like schizophrenia - a mental health condition which affects 220,000 people in the UK- and Kyle is one of them.After a messy break up and losing his job, Kyle tumbled into a bout of depression and began hearing a voice which told him he was worthless and should kill himself.Kyle first heard the voice ten months ago, and since then it has been constantly telling him to jump off buildings and cliffs.I was very, very lost and I think this is why the voice took hold so easily and took control, Kyle says on BBC3 documentary The Voices in My Head.He didnt tell anyone about the voice at first. Instead, he tried to block it out -  using music as a distraction.But after months of torment, Kyle resorted to trying to cut the sinister presence out of his head once and for all.In pure desperation, he took a blade and hacked into his skull just above his right ear - the point where it sounded like the voice was coming from.He passed out from blood loss. When he came to, the voice told him hed killed someone and Kyle believed it.Scared and confused, Kyle told a stranger that hed committed murder, and she called the police.Kyle then ran - fearing hed be locked up - and called his mum.When she found him, he had blood all over his face and had no choice but to confess everything about the voice.He was sent to a mental health ward, where he stayed for a month.Hes now using a combination of medication and therapy to get rid of the voice which has ruined his life - or at least quiet it down - and has a new job as a valet.In many cases, talking with therapists about the origins of voices can help to ease sufferers worries, and many can use the same coping mechanisms as people with anxiety to remain calm during intense episodes.But hell always bear the knife scar on his head, and for many people with schizophrenia, they must live their lives in the knowledge that the voices will never fully go away.Symptoms of schizophrenia can include having muddled thoughts, undergoing behavioural changes, and experiencing hallucinations and delusions.In some people, schizophrenic behaviours start suddenly, while they develop over time for others.Mental health charity Mind says: Some people think hearing voices means someone is dangerous, when voices are actually more likely to suggest that you harm yourself than someone else.Its also important to remember that people have a choice in whether they do what the voices say.The NHS says you should see your GP as soon as possible if you are experiencing the symptoms of schizophrenia.More information is available on the Mind website. Emmalina is sweeping the floor in her kitchen when shes interrupted by a sinister voice.Im going to kill you when you go outside, it says.Nobody else can hear it, but according to Emmalina, its the voice of the devil - a regular presence who torments her at her lowest moments and leaves her too scared to leave the house.Shes been hearing voices since she was eight and talking back to them for the past three years.As well as the devil, she lives with a voice called Katie - her closest friend - and the voice of her mother.Katie helped me get through really tough times when I was younger, Emmalina says.Emmalina endured sexual abuse and bullying in her childhood, and experts say that early trauma is often associated with hearing voices or developing multiple personalities.I wouldnt have got through childhood without Katie, Emmalina says. My life was unbearable.But Katie isnt always supportive of her.Emmalina says that in the past, Katies voice has told her to cut herself and to smash her own wrists with a hammer.The voice also routinely abuses her, calling her a fat b***h while she eats and even filling her head with racial slurs on the rare occasions when she ventures away from home.These days, Emmalina finds it difficult to leave the house at all, thanks to the increasingly frequent influences of the voice she attributes to the devil.Speaking in a sinister, upper-class accent, it routinely tells her that shell be killed if she steps outside.Im going to burn the skin off your bones, it says. Im going to drag you down to hell. Im going to get you.The voices threats have become so debilitating that Emmalina had to leave her job as a nursery assistant, and now relies on a support worker to try and control her condition.Schizophrenia is often misunderstood, and Australian TV show You Cant Ask That recently aired an episode where sufferers address misconceptions about the condition.Sufferers say that taking medication can suppress the voices, but at the height of their illnesses some reported hearing the voices of dead relatives, unborn children and - like Emmalina - the devil.Sandy can hear two voices, one male and one female.“They used to sound really crass in the way they spoke, but in the last 10 years they’ve done elocution, she says on the show.So now my voices abuse me with a posh accent.“They will tell me how evil I am, how disgusting I am, how disgusting I look, how my face is revolting, how if people touch me they will die because I will contaminate them with my oozing evil.”Other schizophrenic episodes have seen sufferers starve themselves - believing they were being told to by the Grim Reaper - and become convinced that theyre the target of government conspiracies.I have this lingering delusion in the back of my mind that Tony Blair has implanted a micro-chip in my left ear to delete my thoughts, Sandy adds.Fellow sufferer Steve adds: I hear voices all the time. Even just sitting here.“In the early days when I was unwell, if I didn’t do what the voices told me to do they would just get louder and louder and louder.For Chaz, the emergence of a voice which she calls Victor almost proved fatal.Victor has been an unwelcome fixture in Chaz life since 2013, but she was too scared of being sectioned to tell anyone about it.The voice heaps constant abuse on her, telling her that she has no right to be alive and that she can end the torment by killing herself.You should die, the voice says, during one particularly nasty outburst. Just die.After eight months of Victors constant goading, Chaz jumped from a bridge.I didnt want to hear it any more and I wanted everything to disappear, she says. I dont really remember being on the bridge.The police shouted my name. I turned towards them, turned back towards the bridge and just stepped off.Today, the former skateboarder is in a wheelchair as the result of the suicide attempt, which left her with a broken foot, two smashed wrists, a fractured pelvis and a fractured sternum.Chaz still hears Victors voice, and it sometimes even teases her about the day she almost died.I put you in a wheelchair, Victor says, and Chaz hears a foul-spirited laugh inside her head.Now, Chaz refuses to let Victor control her life. She writes and recites poetry about her condition to try and drown the voice out, and hopes to find love soon.I know its hard for anyone to be my friend, she says. But I do actually want to meet people. Id like a girlfriend.But its hard to get someone to stay around. Its terrifying to meet someone who doesnt necessarily want to live all day, every day.If you are struggling with suicidal thoughts or mental health issues, or someone you know is, call the Samaritans free of charge on 116 123 Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: find out a level results get your grades what happens next
story: As the day of reckoning approaches, here is what you need to know about finding out whether you will be celebrating or commiserating.This year, judgement day falls on Thursday, August 16, when students will be able to go to their school or college to pick up their results.Students will able to collect their A-level results any time after 6am from their school or college assuming it is open at that time.Pupils will be able to see their university confirmation on UCAS Track from 8am.The Track became available from 8am on Thursday, August 1, 2018, updating records for each applicant.If you get bang on your grades or above you can carry on as planned and prepare to go to the uni that you accepted an offer from earlier in the year.For those who are looking to go to uni but fall short of the requirements come results day, you will still be able to browse the UCAS website for clearing spaces at other universities.Over 64,400 students used clearing in 2015 to get a place at university, so it can be a great tool for those keen to embark on an undergraduate degree.If your A-level results are higher than those required for your firm offer, you are entitled to look around for a university with higher entry requirements if you wish.This is known as the “Adjustment period” and you will be given five days from the date your conditional offer is changed to an unconditional offer to search for a possible alternative.If you haven’t chosen to defer already, you will need to get in touch with the university as soon as your place with them is confirmed to tell them that you wish to defer the offer.Students are advised to bring with them their Ucas letter and contact details for any university offers they have, plus everything youd need to apply through clearing, such as a phone and the Clearing app.It may also be useful to bring a copy of your personal statement and a copy of your reference.People can actually apply through clearing if needed from June 30 – but its most frequently used after results day by people who have just missed out on their grades.It remains open until September, allowing you to contact unis directly if they still have spaces on a course which takes your fancy.

title: sscaffolder lost limbs electric shock splits mum twins burden
story: Scaffolder Jamie Mines, 34, was thrown 13ft from a half-finished roof when the electricity surged through a metal sheet he was holding.Jamie spent ten weeks in intensive care supported by then-girlfriend Harley Ware and their twin daughters Savannah and Isabella.But he has revealed he amicably split from 26-year-old Harley in February and is living alone.He said: We parted on good terms. I just didnt want to be a burden - she had to deal with a lot, looking after me.Now, Jamie who “lives for” his daughters’ visits sees them once a week for a day and overnight, and has thrown himself into fatherhood.Despite his injuries the loving dad is thriving with his four prosthetic limbs, cleaning his home and cooking for himself and his daughters when they visit.Jamie who has learnt to drive thanks to a specially-adapted steering wheel is also aiming to be a Paralympic runner.He said: Im getting fitter each day. I take the girls to the park when theyre here.They like being outdoors, which can be hard for me, because I get tired very quickly.But Ive started going to the gym for an hour every morning, trying to get my energy levels back up to how they were before the accident.The dad of two has care staff visit twice a day, at 12pm and 6pm, to help him around the house - but he says he is able to do most things for himself.He said: I can cook for myself if its something that just needs to go on a baking tray in the oven, and I can boil veg and so on.I can pretty much do most things for myself - I can hoover the house, but the one thing I struggle with is dusting.He added: I have dressed the girls before, but it takes me about an hour to do.So the carer helps me get them dressed and undressed, and helps with bathtimes and nappy changes and things like that.Jamie, who had his final limb, his left leg, removed in July last year, said: I was up and about almost as soon as I had my second prosthetic leg fitted in August.I took to it straight away. I was a bit wobbly at first, but it only took me an hour so to get used to it.The mind is your only barrier. A lot of people who need amputations in adulthood are quite scared of adapting to losing a limb. But I wasnt scared or anything.

title: yellow hire bikes litter uk cities
story: Many of these cheap, dockless rentals, similar to Londons Boris Bikes, often end up dumped in lakes and trees and are leaving pedestrians furious at the litter.Cities such as London, Manchester and Birmingham have seen an influx of the bicycles - brought in by companies such as Ofo.Although billed as a good alternative to driving, many have instead been stolen or vandalised.Photos shared by fed up people show the distinctive yellow bikes on walkways or dumped in rivers.In a couple of bizarre shots the bicycles appear to have been stashed in the branches of a tree and in place of a lifebuoy.The bikes are easy to hire - customers simply download an app where they add their bank details and locate the nearest bike.The camera on the users phone can then be used to unlock the back wheel of the bicycle.Unlike Boris Bikes, the cheaper alternatives are dockless and so can be left wherever the customer chooses to hop off.Hire companies therefore tend to rely on other users reporting any dumped bikes, as a small team looks to locate and fix them.Users can be fined for damage, but the bikes can be moved and abandoned without customers logging their details and paying to rent them.Ofo has more than 250million customers worldwide and has more than 2,000 bikes for hire in London.Michael Hurwitz, director of innovation at Transport for London, told MailOnline: Were working hard to make cycling easier and more accessible across London, so we welcome the growth in dockless cycle hire schemes, as well as growth for our own popular Santander Cycles.However, it is vital that dockless operators work closely with us and the boroughs to ensure their schemes are safely and responsibly managed, so we can avoid the disruptive and dangerous clutter of abandoned bikes that we have seen in some cities around the world.We are pursuing a pan-London approach to managing dockless operators with London Councils, which could include a new bye-law to help ensure that schemes are safe and responsibly managed with local issues in mind.The Sun Online has gone to Ofo for comment.

title: cabinet minister labels labour a cult under jeremy corbyn after his supporters filmed falsely claiming their leader has won the nobel peace prize
story: The supporters of the veteran leftie were using the erroneous assertion as they tried to justify their claims how Mr Corbyn could not be racist.Amid a row about anti-Semitism in the party Mr Corbyn travelled to Stoke to give a speech, and Sky News interviewed a number of Corbynistas as they waited to go in.Every single one claimed the furore over him laying a wreath at the graves of the Munich massacre masterminds was a “smear campaign”.They offered a host of bizarre explanations – with one even suggesting “the Queen lays all kinds of wreaths”.But the most ridiculous was the suggestion Mr Corbyn has sat alongside Malala Yousafzai, Barack Obama and Nelson Mandela as one of the global luminaries to be made a Nobel laureate.Sky News journalist Lewis Goodall said there were more than 400 activists queued to see him speak at the bet365 stadium, tweeting: “Everyone we spoke to agreed: Corbyn is being smeared, Labour does not have a problem with anti-Semitism and that the whole thing is largely concocted by the media and Tories.“His base is completely solid.”He added: “Two party members, entirely separately, told me that Corbyn could not be an anti-Semite because he’s won the Nobel Peace Prize.”It led to the Justice Secretary David Gauke tweeting: “The Labour Party is now a cult.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british olympian at tragic 1972 munich games says jeremy corbyns wreath laying condones the massacre and he is unfit to be pm
story: Fencing professional Edward Hudson said the Labour bosss support for terrorist movements means he should never be allowed near No10.Mr Hudson, now 72 and living in Eye, Suffolk, accused the Labour boss of lop-sided sympathies and urged him to spare a thought for the relatives of those who were slaughtered at the games.He said: I dont think you have potential to be Prime Minister if you have supported terrorist movements.And he accused him of trying to cover up what really happened, adding: I find it worrying. I wish he came out and was absolutely straight and honest.If he wishes to support the Palestinian movement or whatever then do so, but he seems to be hiding every movement hes made behind a smoke screen and shifting the story as its revealed.The Black September group brutally slaughtered 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 games after they stormed the grounds with guns and grenades.Mr Corbyn is under fire for being present at a wreath-laying ceremony for the mastermind of the massacre in Tunisia in 2014.He was even snapped holding a wreath, but claims it was for the 47 victims of an Israeli airstrike in 1985 - which has a memorial in the same area.Yesterday he claimed that there were multiple wreaths laid down for multiple victims.Mr Hudson, who was 26 at the time of the atrocity in Munich, said the British team even considered going home after the tragedy.One of the victims was one of their own - fencing coach Andre Spitzer. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british gran complained spanish benidorm hotel compensation
story: Freda Jackson, 81, demanded a refund for her Thomas Cook holiday after claiming she was left in tears because it was teeming with rude Spanish natives.The OAP from Blackburn, Lancs, had said: The hotel was full of Spanish holidaymakers and they really got on our nerves because they were just so rude.One evening a Spanish guy nearly knocked me flying and he just walked off without even apologising.The entertainment in the hotel was all focused and catered for the Spanish - why cant the Spanish go somewhere else for their holidays?However, her comments have sparked outrage in Spain, with thousands claiming it was a cynical ploy to cash in.Scores of everyday Spaniards have now waded into the debate.Martin Esteban said: I would like to remind Mrs. Jackson, that Benidorm is Spain, if she is not happy that she stays in her country, as well as the people of her country who come to get drunk.Rosa Humanes said: These English do not know what to do to have free vacations, adding that now the bargain of gastroenteritis has run out they make bulls*** new claims.Lucia Garcia Sanchez posted: You have to read between the lines. What she wants is for vacations to (be) free.The hotel itself said that Jackson had only made one complaint, and this was about the location of her room, which was changed at her request.Freda has since been offered compensation of £566 from Thomas Cook due to an error informing her about a change to her flights.A Thomas Cook spokesperson told The Sun Online: Due to a system error Ms Jackson was not informed of a change to her flights until six days before departure.We have offered Ms Jackson and her travel companion a gesture of goodwill to try and put things right which we hope she will accept.

title: womans lost contact lens lodged behind eye
story: The now 42-year-old assumed the contact lens had fallen out, but in fact it had moved behind her eye - yet didnt cause any symptoms for years.Then suddenly, six months before doctors discovered the lens, the unnamed woman started experiencing pain and swelling behind her eye.It appeared the size of a pea to start with, but still didnt causing any discomfort. Quickly it began to grow larger and became painful to touch.She was referred to an eye specialist at NHS Teeside by her GP, but the cause of the swelling remained a mystery.There was no scarring or inflammation on the upper eyelid, just a lump close to her nose.An MRI of the eye showed a cyst behind her left eye and she required surgery to remove it.It was during the surgery that doctors realised the cyst was a hard contact lens.But it still didnt explain where the contact lens had come from.Then her mother remembered that she was hit in the eye with a shuttlecock while playing badminton when she was 14.At the time she was wearing contact lenses but one of them wasnt found, so they assumed it fell out.She suffered swelling around the eye that eventually went down and she never wore hard contact lenses again.We can infer that the lens migrated into the patient’s left upper eyelid at the time of trauma and had been in situ for the last 28 years, Dr Sirjhun Patel wrote in the BMJ case report.The patient also had a droopy left eyelid, which doctors assumed was also caused by the rogue contact lens.Her vision was not damaged and she made a full recovery once the lens was removed.The migration of a rigid gas permeable (RGP) lens into the eyelid is a rare cause of eyelid swelling, Dr Patel added.Spontaneous migration of a hard contact lens into the eyelid is a relatively known occurrence, but we were only able to find four reported cases of lens migration secondary to significant trauma.This case report exhibits the longest time between traumatic RGP lens migration into the eyelid and presentation of eyelid swelling.

title: labour mp refuses six times to say jeremy corbyn is fit to be pm and hints he could be ousted as leader next month
story: Madeleine Moon failed six times when asked to say if the Labour leader was fit to become Prime Minister.She blasted him for dominating newspaper headlines with negative coverage over his controversial trip to Tunisia in 2014.He has admitted he laid a wreath to honour members of the Black September terrorists who killed 11 Israeli athletes at the Munich 1972 - but refused to apologise to the widows for attending.After pictures emerged of him at the ceremony at a cemetery in Tunis, Mr Corbyn initially denied he was involved - saying he was marking the deaths of 47 people in Israeli airstrikes in 1985.But he has since changed his story several times, and now faces a House of Commons probe over failing to properly declare the trip to the authorities.The Labour boss has come under increasing pressure this week, which comes on the back of the partys ongoing anti-Semitism crisis.And today Ms Moon, the MP for Bridgend, hinted that Mr Corbyn could face moves to oust him as early as Labour’s annual conference in Liverpool next month.She told TalkRadio: “Individuals as leaders come and go. And the party will look at this I am sure extremely forcefully at the next conference.Lets wait and see what conference decides.“Theres always a rule in politics: if youre on the front pages for too long you become the story and thats not good because you miss all the good and effective things that the Labour Party is doing in terms of policy and holding this government to account.”Host Julia Hartley-Brewer asked her: “Do you think that a man who lays wreaths at the tombs of terrorists who have killed innocent people is fit to be the British Prime Minister?”But Ms Moon would only reply: “That will be a decision for the British people.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: worlds freakiest animals giant horse headed bats five legged frogs
story: The terrifying beast - dubbed the flying donkey - proves Mother Nature likes to have a bit of fun every now and then.However, as these baffling wildlife photographs show, some of her creations are as scary as they are bizarre.Here are just a few of the weird and wonderful animals that have to be filed under the heading Freaks of Nature.One image shows a freakish five-legged frog that should have no problems hopping around.

title: san jose galleon treasure hunter claims he discovered the ship in 1982 and says hes entitled to half its 12bn fortune
story: Jack Harbeston says he can prove his company discovered the lost ship off the coast of Colombia back in 1982.He is the director of Sea Search Armada, which claims to have given the Colombian government its location 36 years ago after finding it 11 miles off the coast of Cartagena.The 62-gun, three-masted galleon, went down on June 8, 1708, with 600 people on board as well as a treasure of gold, silver and emeralds during a battle with British ships in the War of Spanish Succession.The treasure is estimated to be worth as much as £12.6billion by modern standards.For centuries its location was known as the holy grail of shipwrecks, and long considered one of historys greatest maritime mysteries.However, in 2015 the government publicly declared that THEY had discovered the wreck - at a different site with the help of other organisations - setting in motion a complicated legal drama.Jack claims this was a government attempt to avoid paying him riches legally determined to be worth 50 percent of the shipwrecks value.He also says there ARE tiny discrepancies in the location of the treasure, but this is due to modern improvements in tracking technology.He says hes now prepared to take legal action in Colombia, while also pursue compensation under the USs Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.Muddying the waters further is a recent announcement from another company, the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute (WHOI), revealing new details of the discovery they supposedly helped the government make in 2015.Jack told The Sun Online: Why did the WHOI finally break its silence... to now claim credit for finding the San Jose?WHOIs contract with the Government of Colombia to search for the San Jose, included a nondisclosure paragraph that (ex-Colombia President) Santos used to take all the credit for WHOIs work.WHOI got tired of seeing everybody else take credit.Presumably the agreement terminated, so WHOI had a press conference to take full credit for finding the San Jose.The Sun Online has requested comment from WHOI.Rob Munier, WHOIs vice president for marine facilities and operations, has previously said: Weve been holding this under wraps out of respect for the Colombian government.The cargo was destined to help Spain’s King Philip V fund his war against Britain.However, frequent voyages by Spanish treasure ships had led to a golden age of piracy - with raiders sinking more than 1,000 Spanish ships off the coast of Colombia during three centuries of colonial rule.The San Joses 600-strong crew knew the voyage would be fraught with danger. But they were barely 16 miles out when they were tracked down by English Commodore Charles Wager, in command of four British ships including HMS Expedition.Wager’s plan was to seize the San José, the largest ship in the fleet. But before it could be boarded, something went terribly wrong and the San José blew up.Writing in his log, Wager described an explosion so intense that he could feel the heat from his own ship.He wrote: I believe the ship’s side blew out, for she caused a sea that came in our ports. She immediately sank with all her riches.

title: woman apologises pushing taylor smith bridge canada
story: Jordan Holgerson cracked five ribs and punctured her lung and “could have died” after belly-flopping into the Lewis River in Vancouver, Washington, on Tuesday.The Sun Online revealed that Taylor was later seen partying with friends “as if nothing happened” after the shove which left her friend unable to walk.The teen was caught posing with a friend at the Clark County Fair in a post on Instagram on Saturday.A close family source told Sun Online: “Taylor has been going out as if nothing happened.“Shes been at a pool party and there were pictures of her at the county fair with a friend on Instagram. Jordan can hardly walk and is in so much pain - she cant do any of those things.“Taylor hasnt been to visit Jordan to see if she is ok. She clearly doesnt care. She messaged Jordan to say sorry but nobody thinks it was a sincere apology.According to sources, Taylor has left school, is unemployed and lives with her grandmother.Jordan has told how she blacked out as she was abruptly pushed off the edge of the bridge.She told told a local website: “In midair I think I mightve blacked out... I was awake and aware when I hit the water.”Someone had to swim out to rescue her before she was taken to the nearby PeaceHealth Southwest Medical Center in Vancouver.Ashley Mahree, the girl who recorded and shared the video online, said: “This looks to be almost criminal.”She wrote in the YouTube description: “This could have easily taken a life, and I think this girl needs to be held accountable in some way.”Sun Online has reached out to Taylor and her grandmother for comment.Jordans auntie Kristie Morgan revealed her niece has been physically and emotionally scarred by the fall but she does not wish revenge on her pusher.She said Jordan, who woke up in hospital crying in pain, finally went home on Friday but is suffering panic attacks since plummeting off Moulton Falls Bridge .Another family member told The Sun Online what Taylor did was horrible, but they dont wish anything bad against her.Photos from a GoFundMe page raising money for Jordans recovery showed her lounging against a giant teddy bear with a hospital tag around her wrist.They were worlds apart from the snaps, taken from her hospital bed, which showed Jordan with a neck brace and unsightly scars on her inner thigh and ribs.The crowd-sourcing page claimed the schoolgirl had damaged the lining in her uterus and is constantly in pain.Kristie added: She is really suffering physically and emotionally. She went home last night and woke up crying in pain this morning.She had previously taken to Facebook to demand the police take action against the woman who shoved her.Kristie added: She doesnt wish to seek revenge on her friend. But in my opinion her friend needs to learn a lesson.She could have killed her and it wouldnt be a question at all if she was in trouble for her actions. She would be in jail right now. But that is how Jordan feels.”Her mum told Thoroughbred Daily News that her daughter is lucky not be paralysed or dead.Jordan and her friends had climbed up to the bridge with the intention of jumping but as she stood on the edge, she had second thoughts.Clearly scared as she looked down at the water below, one of her so-called pals gave her an aggressive and abrupt shove in the back.Rather than falling feet first and streamlined, Jordan plunged with her arms and legs flailing wildly before hitting the water with almighty clap.She later told a local website: In midair I think I mightve blacked out... I was awake and aware when I hit the water.Someone had to swim out to rescue her before she was taken to the nearby PeaceHealth Southwest Medical Center in Vancouver.One of Jordans sisters, Kaytlin, said she confronted the girl who pushed her on social media, demanding an apology.She told local site KOIN: Friends dont push someone from that high... I was p****d. She pretty much said that she was sorry for doing it and she wouldnt have done it if she knew the outcome.I think the girl that pushed her should have some sort of consequence because you wont learn your lesson if you think you can could do that again and think it will be fine.Ashley Mahree, the girl who recorded and shared the video online, said: This looks to be almost criminal.She wrote in the YouTube description: This could have easily taken a life, and I think this girl needs to be held accountable in some way.Kristie has set up a GoFundMe page to raise money for her Jordan’s medical bills.Clark County Fire Chief Ben Peeler confirmed it is illegal to jump from the bridge.

title: allergic reactions bee sting swollen lips
story: That’s because these aren’t beauty treatments that have gone too far – they are in fact horrible allergic reactions to bee stings.Wasp and bee stings are really common especially during the warmer months when people are spending more time outdoors.Symptoms of a severe allergic reaction include extreme swelling of the face, lips or throat, as well as breathing difficulties.The swelling usually subsides after a few days – but sufferers are often left looking like they’ve been at the collagen as they wait for the effects to wear off.While an antihistamine and ice pack often help to calm the reaction, they can sometimes require a visit to the emergency room.And while it can be a terribly painful ordeal to go through, some of these people ended up with rather enviable pouts while others ended up looking like botox gone very wrong.

title: turkey tariffs us imports alcohol tobacco cars
story: Alcohol tariffs were raised to 140 per cent, while tobacco rose to 60 per cent, and cars rose to 120 percent.Rice and coal were also hit with new tariffs.The lira made modest gains after the move, increasing in value by three per cent, helped along by other measures aimed at stopping foreign investors speculating on the currency.The US-Turkey dispute revolves around jailed evangelical preacher Andrew Brunson, who was arrested on terrorism charges in Turkey 22 months ago.Trump is believed to be taking a hard line because much of his supporter base are evangelicals.The US is threatening further sanctions if Brunson is not released in the coming weeks.Talks between Turkey and the US on Monday night ended in an impasse.Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan accused the US of plotting to destabilise the country and pledged to seek new international trading partners.They may have taken their first step this morning, freeing Lieutenant Angelos Mitretodis and Sergeant Dimitris Kouklatzis, two Greek soldiers held on espionage charges for five months.They returned to Greece this morning, and some believe the move was calculated to win favour with Europe as Turkey faces off against Washington.On Monday the lira dipped to its lowest value ever against the US dollar - trading at only just over seven lira to the dollar.The lira was already in a delicate position before Trump slapped harsh sanctions on the Nato-member state - technically a US ally - due to tension over Erdogan’s increasing authoritarianism.President Erdogan described the currency slide as a storm in a teacup and said there was no economic crisis, and the decline was down to an operation against Turkey.During a speech to supporters in Trabzon on the Black Sea coast, Erdogan proposed counter-measures, including a movement away from reliance on the dollar and US markets.There are fears of mass panic in Turkey, with one major bank reportedly blocking customers from opening new foreign exchange accounts, making it harder for people to trade lira for US dollars, pounds and euros.On Monday Erdogan reportedly referred to America as The bullies of the global system.The bitter tensions are also likely to cause a stir in Nato, of which Turkey is a member, and Erdogan has hinted he may seek new allies as a result of the sanctions.The lira made a modest recovery on Monday after the central bank pledged to provide funds and cut reserve requirements for Turkish banks.Many emerging economics such as Argeninta and South Africa could suffer from the crisis, given their exposure to Turkish debt.

title: pressure mounts on tory peer who attended tunisia conference with corbyn as mps demand hes expelled from the party
story: In a joint letter Robert Halfon and Zac Goldsmith said the Tories would be guilty of “double standards” if they fail to throw him out - and would nullify their attacks on the Labour boss over his links to Palestinian terrorists.Mr Goldsmith wrote: “If this man is not immediately expelled from the Conservative Party, the Party hierarchy’s complaints about Corbyn will look entirely cynical.”The peer was formally reported to the Conservative party board after it emerged he attended the controversial 2014 Tunis ‘peace conference’ along with a string of extremists, including a Hamas leader who called violence “magnificent”.Tory party chairman Brandon Lewis wrote a 1,200 article branding Mr Corbyn “unfit for senior public office” due to his appearance at the conference.In their formal complaint about Sheikh Mr Halfon and Mr Goldsmith said the “disgraceful nature” of the conference he attended with Mr Corbyn warranted a full inquiry.Their letter to the party states: “We cannot, as a Party, rightly and robustly criticise the Leader of the Opposition for his attendance at this conference while allowing the attendance of a Conservative Peer at the same event to pass without comment or complaint. To do so would be to indulge in hypocrisy and double standards.”And Andrew Percy also filed a separate complaint about Lord Sheikh and demanded the whip be suspended from him.Lord Sheikh was the peer who reported Boris Johnson to the party over his controversial burqa comments.In a lengthy statement defending his attendance at the conference Lord Sheikh said he didn’t meet any members of Hamas, didn’t participate in the controversial wreath-laying ceremony and said he was an active campaigner against anti-Semitism.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: callie rogers teen lotto winner dogsitters
story: Callie — who scooped £1.87million aged 16 — was kicked, punched and stamped on by Marie Hinde, 37, and Jade Quayle, 26.They dragged her around a living room “like a rag doll” and left her bloodied and needing hospital treatment.The pair are now facing jail after admitting the assault.It is the latest blow Callie, 31, has faced since her win in 2003.She suffered depression and attempted suicide after blowing her cash on drugs, boob ops and designer clothes.On the night of the attack in July last year she was in a taxi heading to her then boyfriend’s.She told the driver: “Dont worry about your money. I’ve still got £3,000 left — I’m that girl that won the lottery.”Her boyfriend was not at home but Hinde and Quayle, who had been dogsitting, were there.A row developed and they attacked Callie, who felt kicks to her face and stamps to her body, Carlisle crown court heard.She thought she blacked out at one stage of the 2am attack in Whitehaven, Cumbria.The case against Hinde, of Whitehaven, and Quayle, of Cleator Moor, was this week adjourned for sentencing on September 14.Callie spoke out last week about how miserable the lottery win had made her.She had been working as a checkout girl when she won but immediately gave up her job for a life of wild partying.She blew all her money, spending £250,000 on cocaine, £18,000 on three boob jobs and £300,000 on clothes.She also gave at least £500,000 to family and friends and later realised some used her for cash.She told ITV’s This Morning: “It just became too much to cope with... all the stress of having the money. I wanted to go back to having a normalNot knowing who loved me for me and who was using me and who I could trust. Still, at 31, I have trust issues. There were a lot of false people involved.”The mum of three called for the age limit for buying a lottery ticket to be raised to 18 and said: “At 16 you are still just a child. It nearly broke me.”She is now in a relationship and carer for youngest son Blake, six, who has cerebral palsy.The Government is reviewing the age limit of 16 for buying lottery tickets..Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ed hyatt 1823 8 minutes ago to felix me
story: Katia Rouarch confirmed the F1 drivers move to the sprawling pile is imminent in an interview with weekly Swiss magazine L’Illustre.Politician Rouarch, who became mayoress of Andratx in June, told the Lausanne-based magazine: “I can officially confirm Michael Schumacher is going to move in to our municipality and that everything is being prepared to welcome him.”L’Illustre said she had confirmed the news to its correspondent but no-one on the island had been able to say when Schumacher, 50 in January, would arrive or how long his stay would be.It was reported last month that Corinna had bought Real Madrid president Florentino Perez’s Majorcan mansion for nearly £27million.The huge property near Andratx features two swimming pools, a large garden, a helipad, a guest villa and stunning sea views.Aerial pictures show the propertys sprawling garden which features dozens of trees.Schumachers family has remained private about his life since the seven-time F1 champion suffered a catastrophic brain injury while skiing in December 2013. Since then, the family has been based in Switzerland.Michael, 49, and Corinna, who married in 1995, previously holidayed on the island of Majorca before his devastating accident.Michael was put into a medically induced coma for six months after suffering a life-threatening brain injury.The German racing legend is believed to be receiving full-time care at his home.In 2016, his lawyer told a court Schumacher cannot walk in response to speculation in German media about his condition.German tabloid Bild said Corinna had purchased the exclusive property so she could spend holidays there with her children and friends.The house was bought for £22million by building magnate Perez in 2005, but he put it up for sale last year after the death of his wife Mari Angeles Sandoval.The property was put up for sale last year.

title: thief dublin tied lamppost tourist
story: Passers-by in Ireland laughed at the hopeless thief after a US tourist trussed him up in Dublin city centre and waited for the cops to arrive.Eye-witnesses say the tourist from Florida – described as a “big man” with a motorcycle - gave the would-be thief a “few digs”.The Gardai were called but while the tourist waited passersby took the opportunity to take a few pictures of the man who was tied up and posted them online.A source told Dublin Live that the tourist was a big man who had been outside a shop with a Harley-DavidsonHe said: The (local) man then approached him and tried to take his bag and phone but Id say he regrets it now.He wont be doing that again any time soon.Pictures online show the alleged thief dressed in a red shirt and blue jean being confronted by the tourist who is wearing motorcycle gear.Other pictures then show the man tied to the lamppost and other show him being led away by the police.Irish cops confirmed the incident, saying they were called at around 6.30pm today.Yesterday evening a teenage girl was stabbed in the face in Dublin during a robbery at 7.20pm in the Golden Lane area of the city.

title: virgin media broadband workers holes in customers walls
story: Furious internet users have complained of abysmal service from the provider, with one customer claiming that a vast 10in hole left in his wall by an engineer hadnt been repaired in six weeks.Writing on Twitter, Andrew Mabbitt said: So @virginmedia broke my wall on an installation 6 weeks ago, said theyd fix it and never did &amp left me on hold on the phone for one moment and never came back.Why on earth do I pay so much money for this service? Abysmal.Mr Mabbitt, director of cyber-security firm Fidus Information Security, told the BBC that the engineer who botched the installation was incredibly apologetic.But he said the company had failed to follow-up on their promise that it would be fixed.Got a call the next day from Virgin saying theyd be in touch soon to arrange a date and they never called back, he said.Mr Mabbitt added that he also tried to contact the firm via its online chat service - but claims it was not working at that time.British soldier Dom Valentine also complained that a Virgin Media engineer left a large drill bit stuck in his wall for more than a week in his military accommodation.He told the BBC that the engineer drilled into a metal part inside the wall, which caused the drill bit to get stuck.The engineer then apparently tried it from the outside of the building, with little success.He was hitting it with a hammer which has now cracked the bricks on the other side, said Mr Valentine.Virgin Media offered him £20 credit but he said the firm has not followed up on providing a repair.I was told the area manager would get back to me, which he hasnt, added Mr Valentine.A spokeswoman for Ofcom told the BBC that since 1 June the regulator had received 10 complaints about damage to property left by Virgin Media workers and three relating to work done by Openreach.A spokesman for Virgin Media told the Sun Online: “Were already speaking to the small number of customers referenced and some of these issues have already been resolved.The vast majority of the hundreds of thousands of installs we carry out each year are completed to the high standards we expect.

title: 3 year tenancies landlords government
story: The Sun can reveal that Communities Secretary James Brokenshire is backing calls to make three-year terms mandatory across England and Wales despite fierce opposition from private landlords.A formal decision is due to be announced by the Government next week.Scotland implemented ‘indefinite’ tenancies last year.One source told The Sun: “Landlords won’t be able to just chuck out tenants after a year and jack up the rent.James wants to give tenants the security they need through mandatory, three-year leases.”Ministers proposed three-year tenancies in July but said one option was to allow landlords a “voluntary” opt-out.Another was to offer tax breaks to encourage landlords to adopt them.A move to mandatory three-year deals – while allowing tenants a break-clause if they want a shorter deal – will delight campaigners.The private rented sector accounts for 4.7 million people or 20 per cent of households – up 74 per cent in the past decade. Around 46 per cent of 25 to 34 year-olds now live in private rentals as house prices rocket.Some 80 per cent of the tenancies in England and Wales are set at six or 12 months.Charities warned this leaves tenants at the risk of eviction at short notice- and demanded a change.Shelter chief Polly Neate last night said the Government’s decision was “very good news” that would transform the lives of many struggling to make ends meet.She said: “The current renting system is a complete mess, with families teetering on the edge of blink-and-you-miss-it six-month contracts – barely enough time to set your broadband up, let alone see your kids through school.“This problem will not be fixed by giving landlords a tax break to coax them into doing what everyone should be doing anyway.”Shelter earlier this week said 55 per cent of private renters believe longer tenancies would improve their situation.And they claimed two-thirds of renters would think better of a political party that brought in longer contracts.GOT a story? title: housing price slow rate london south east
story: The Office for National Statistics said average prices increased by 3 per cent to £228,000 in the 12 months to August – the weakest annual growth since 2013.But prices in the capital during the year fell by 0.7 per cent.Upmarket Kensington &amp Chelsea saw a 10 per cent drop in June – the biggest monthly fall since current records began in 1995.The ONS added the annual rate of home sales across the UK has dropped to a five year low of 66,000.
