title: face up what youve done
story: News'Face up to what you’ve done': Speedboat crash victim's heartbroken family urge fugitive killer to face justiceEXCLUSIVE: Charlotte Brown’s older sisters Katie, 29, and Vicky, 31, from Dartford, Kent, write an open letter to Jack ShepherdShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJulie McCaffrey22:30, 15 AUG 2018NewsTragic Charlotte Brown (middle) seen here with her sisters Katie (left), and Vicky (right)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen beloved sister and daughter Charlotte “Charli” Brown was killed in a speedboat crash on the Thames in London, her family were heartbroken. The 24-year-old was on a first date with web designer Jack Shepherd, whom she met online. He was trying to impress her with the champagne-fulled trip past the Houses of Parliament but drove at twice the speed limit, before the boat hit a log and tipped over. Shepherd, 30, went on the run instead of facing trial but was found guilty of manslaughter by gross negligence in his absence and jailed for six years. His refusal to face justice has left Charli’s family grief-stricken, frustrated, and with endless unanswered questions about that night in December 2015. Here Charli’s older sisters Katie, 29, and Vicky, 31, from Dartford, Kent, write an open letter to Shepherd.   Dear Jack Shepherd,  We both want you to know the terrible impact losing Charli has had on our lives. Katie heard the news of her death after a morning teaching science to secondary school children. A colleague gave her the message: “Please call your mum – &shysomething has happened to your sister.” She wondered if Vicky, who was eight-and-a-half months pregnant, had her baby prematurely. But as soon as Katie heard mum’s sobs and words: “It’s Charli”, she said: “What has he done?” Call it intuition or a premonition, but somehow Katie just knew something had gone terribly wrong the night before. It began during your date when Charli started sending WhatsApp messages telling of the food you ate at the restaurant, and champagne on the speedboat.  That evening, Katie’s second last message to Charli said: “Please let me know you have you survived this &shyescapade?” Charli didn’t answer. That night Katie couldn’t sleep. First thing the next day, she texted her concern: “Charli, are you alive?” That message wasn’t delivered to Charli’s phone, found in her pocket when they pulled her body from the river. Vicky was having a check up at the maternity hospital when she took mum’s call. She had a panic attack. Vicky remembers nothing except the sound of her own wailing. Hearing our baby sister was dead was the worst moment of our lives, until we had to identify her body. We went to the mortuary together with our parents, all hoping it wasn’t our Charli. As soon as we walked into the room and saw her, Mum and Vicky collapsed. Such deep trauma was dangerous for Vicky at such a late stage in pregnancy.  Her due date was December 29. But because of the distress caused by losing Charli, Vicky suffered a series of mini strokes and was admitted to hospital on December 20. She was induced for her and her baby’s safety, and because Charli’s funeral was planned for January 5 2016, and Vicky was terrified she’d go into labour as we said our final goodbyes. Because of you, Charli never met her gorgeous youngest nephew Edward, who was born on Boxing Day. Now Edward is two, the same age as your child who is growing up fatherless. Coming back to serve your time, and seeing your child, is surely better than a lifetime on the run, constantly looking over your shoulder? We urge you directly: give us answers and give yourself up. To any of your friends reading this, please know the net is closing in so you’re just delaying the inevitable. Jack, you’re young so facing justice and serving your time still gives you a chance of having a life, career and family.  Your reckless and cavalier attitude robbed Charli of that chance. But you can never take our memories of our glamorous, bubbly little sister. We remember Charli’s lovely confidence which made her comfortable meeting Vicky’s in-laws for the first time wearing huge rollers in her hair. We can laugh remembering her fearsome competitiveness playing crazy golf. We are both eaten up with anger about the loss of Charli, we both have an empty feeling of grief which feels like it will never end and a sense of living in constant shock. Our pain is indescribable. We were brought up as three very close sisters often mistaken for triplets and are now only two. At family Christmases, weddings and anniversaries we lay a place for Charli at the table. Seeing it empty makes every happy occasion sad. We spend Charli’s birthday at her grave. Time isn’t healing. We hurt just as much as we did in those first few weeks after Charli’s death. Our bereavement left us unable to function. Yet you married a woman you’d got pregnant within a month of the tragedy. We are stuck in an emotional fog because when you fled the court case, you stole our chance of closure and left us with unanswered questions.  You might expect us to lash out with threats or name-calling. But our family has too much dignity and decency. We know you don’t have a shred of either – because if you had a tiny speck of a conscience you’d have turned up at the Old Bailey to finally answer questions about the night you killed our sister. Instead, showing complete lack of respect for us and the legal system, you ran away. Your barrister excused your absence as cowardice. It’s also extreme arrogance and despicable selfishness. We wanted to hear what really happened that night you took Charli out on the Thames in a speedboat bought on Gumtree to “pull women”, as you smirkingly told police. Now we might never know. Why did you pester Charli for a date, tracking her down on Facebook after she blocked you on a dating site? When you knew of the dangerous debris in the Thames, why did you drive the boat at more than twice the speed limit in the dark?  Why take such risks while so drunk you didn’t know Charli’s name, or your own next of kin, when you were in the ambulance? We believe Charli would have survived if she had worn a life jacket. Why on earth didn’t you offer her one when you had two on board? So many questions. But our main one is: do you have any remorse? In the oppressively dark grief we searched for something good to come from Charli’s death. That has to be our petition to clarify and tighten laws covering dangerous driving and drinking while in control of a private boat. We won’t stop until we have at least 10,000 signatures so the Government will consider amending the very loose laws. Hopefully new rules will save lives and will one day be known as ‘Charli’s Law’.

title: football league club fans ordered
story: NewsLuton Town FC fans ordered to stop Tommy Robinson chantsLuton Town's chief executive has urged the Hatters fans to stop singing chants in favour of the far-right activistShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent16:36, 15 AUG 2018Updated17:41, 15 AUG 2018NewsFans have been told to stop singing non-football songs (Image: PA)Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLuton Town supporters have been ordered to stop Tommy Robinson chants . The club's chief executive has told fans their away game at Albion was blemished for the second away game running after a small number were singing in support of the jailed far-right activist. The club brought 1,175 supporters to the Black Country for their Carabao Cup first round match against West Bromwich Albion on Tuesday. Luton’s fans were heard singing light-hearted songs including “Where’s your boiler gone?” referring to the absent mascot from Albion’s sponsors Ideal Boilers, and “Stacey’s too good for you”, joking about the opposition's recent interest in their full-back Jack Stacey. Luton CEO Gary Sweet said: “Apart from the result, our experience was blemished, for the second away game running, by hearing the chanting the name of a political figurehead by a small number of Hatters supporters,” said Sweet. “This is hugely disappointing for us, as a board, because the individual in question wasn’t playing or involved in the squad or staff.  Sweet said the club had worked and would continue to work extremely hard to create an environment for supporters to enjoy a football match without political, religious, cultural or racial prejudice. “This allows us to invite anybody into our environment without discomfort, disrespect or fear, and welcome any and every member of our wide community respectfully, he said. “Luton and Luton Town Football Club is intertwined in a rich tapestry of continuous change and diversity and, for me, the success of embracing such difference has always been ideologically characteristic of ‘being Lutonian’. “We absolutely accept and respect the fact that everyone holds their own independent opinions and values, but we politely ask for you to temporarily overlook those views for a couple of hours or so when attending Luton Town matches in future. “Please respect others when supporting our great club, please support the players on the pitch and please refrain from introducing non-football songs into our stadia.”

title: heres pedestrianising parliament square really
story: NewsopinionHere's why pedestrianising Parliament Square is a really terrible ideaIt'll only send the terrorists to TescoShare&nbspByFleet Street FoxColumnist13:44, 15 AUG 2018Updated14:12, 15 AUG 2018NewsopinionGet politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailApart from the individual horror of being mown down by a speeding vehicle, yesterday's terror attack on Parliament was mostly harmless. No-one died. The terrorist was caught alive. There is no martyr, and if the worst they can do is smack their heads against a reinforced anti-terrorist barrier next to the most heavily-guarded building in Britain then, frankly, there's not a lot to lose sleep over.  Except there is, because as with every terror attack the hardest questions that must be asked are not, while official knees jerk to protect themselves.  Attacks on Parliament bring home to MPs that they are targets for those who take exception to their views, their politics or their existence. It's natural that after the second car-based attempt at mass murder on their place of work in 17 months, they would start to think that cars might be the problem. Only we don't say men are the problem, even though every single terror attack carried out on our shores of late has been conducted by people with testicles. The Islamists who have attacked us may have been Muslims, people of colour, slightly-thick zealots, and one-time petty criminals, but we have not and will not outlaw all such people for the crimes of a few. Boris Johnson would be stuffed, for a start. Yet some say it's time to pedestrianise Parliament Square. Because terrorists are never on foot, are they?   Terrorists have never been in cars, then got out of them to kill someone, have they?    Terrorists have never targeted places where all their potential victims are walking or sitting down, have they?   Terrorists are always the driver, aren't they?  Terror attacks often lead to changes, many of them useful. When the IRA bombed the Grand Hotel in Brighton it led to stringent security measures for party political conferences. After 6 were killed and 50 injured at the Westminster Bridge terror attack, Theresa May promised another &pound50m for counter-terrorism, having earlier been criticised for cuts.  And let's not be too architecturally-conservative about Parliament Square. It was laid out only in 1868, around the same time as the Victorians rebuilt the Houses of Parliament. It is a space owned by the Greater London Authority, which has the power to make bylaws for it, and has used this power in recent years to repeatedly curb the right to protest.  While there is a right to assembly on any public highway, on the roads around Parliament you must ask for police permission. So, on the face of it, pedestrianising the area - putting even the roads under local authority control, banning cars which happens anyway for approved protests, and keeping weapons-on-wheels away from the seat of our democracy - may seem like a sound idea. But it isn't.  Manchester Arena is not a public space, is privately-owned, and keeps its concert-goers away from vehicles. Salman Abedi still managed to blow himself and 22 others to pieces, killing and injuring huge numbers of children.   Abedi used a backpack and a suitcase. Parliament Square attracts millions of tourists a year, most of them with backpacks and suitcases.  Perhaps police and politicians would like bollards at the entrance to the square to include x-ray scanners, to catch those carrying bombs or knives in their backpacks?  In which case, we can look forward to everyone with a penknife or nail scissors being stopped, liquids being bagged and belts and shoes removed at the entrance to the square, just as they already are when you attempt to enter Parliament itself. And anyone who wishes to stage a protest or go to the TV studios at Millbank to criticise the government, will not only have to seek formal approval but be questioned as to their purpose on the way in and the way out. At this uncomfortably-authoritarian juncture, it might be wise to remind ourselves of the few times in recent history that Parliamentarians have actually been attacked.  Jo Cox MP was shot and stabbed on the roadside in Birstall, West Yorkshire in 2016 while on her way to meet constituents.  Stephen Timms MP was stabbed twice at a constituency surgery in a library in Beckton, east London in 2010.  More recently, Conservative life peer David Prior was the victim of a pig blood-based graffiti attack in his own home by an angry ex-girlfriend. When a brick was thrown through Angela Eagle's office, Stella Creasy was threatened with rape and Jess Phillips given death threats, it happened either in their own constituencies or online. And who could forget when deputy Labour leader John Prescott was egged outside a theatre in Rhyl, north Wales, in 2001 when on his way to a political rally.  As yet, no Islamist has yet come within 10 yards of a Parliamentarian at Parliament. Those who have launched attacks outside have not got in, and it has become quite apparent that while cars are good at killing pedestrians, they are rubbish at getting past armed police officers, metal barriers and brick walls.  Of course a Parliamentarian could be outside on his bike, as others were yesterday, or walking over Westminster Bridge, or coming through the gate at the wrong time. So could any one of a thousand other humans, and it is not for the public's sake anyone has suggested banning vehicles.  It has been suggested purely to look like something is being done - even though that thing would not deter a single terrorist. We have yet to hear of an incident averted because a devoted Islamist saw a 'keep off the grass' sign. They are not known for being law-abiding, and it should be noted that this latest attack involved an illegal turn on the wrong side of the road, in clear contravention of the Highway Code.  You can say this for cars being used as weapons - they tend to at least keep the driver alive. And if you ask any counter-terrorism officer what he'd like most after a terror attack, he'd say someone to interrogate.  He might further point out that, in his ideal world, the terrorists come to him. They choose the most-guarded, secure and bristling-with-police-officers building in the country, and run at it one at a time, almost as though they were idiots.  Parliament is a place that can handle terror. Blocking it off to cars does not stop terrorists - it just moves them down the road, to Tesco or the Tower of London or Top Shop. And there isn't a person on the planet who can't see that an attack on soft targets is not only easier for even the most stupid of zealots to manage, but it'll kill an awful lot more people.   Pedestrianisation is the go-to solution for every politician from the local town hall to Downing Street. Banning cars is the only way they can think of to boost local cafes, cut pollution and, now, protect democracy. Never mind that business rates, car manufacturers and sanity might all have more to do with it.  The ability to drive, in cars, taxis or buses, and to walk or cycle unhindered, through Parliament Square does two important things. First, it means millions of us get to see the place close up. On visits, school trips, holidays, the daily commute and in tiny glimpses on our way to somewhere else, we are reminded it is there, and that it is ours. If it were pedestrianised it would be seen only by those who seek it out. And secondly, it tells the terrorists - these dense meat-sacks who could not in any other situation terrify a wet kitten - that we are unmoved. Our democracy has survived worse, and it will survive them.

title: tory peer defends attending same
story: NewsTory peer defends attending same Tunis conference as Jeremy Corbyn after attack from fellow Conservativeshe said the trip, paid for by the Tunisian Government, was properly declared, and he only attended part of it because he was "very tired"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter17:28, 15 AUG 2018Updated17:29, 15 AUG 2018NewsLord Sheikh attended the same conference (Image: SWNS)Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A Tory peer who attended the same conference in Tunisia that has put Jeremy Corbyn under fire has spoken out, insisting he only stayed for part of it because he was very tired.  Lord Sheikh has faced a barrage of complaints from fellow Tories for attending the 2014 conference.  Conservative MPs Robert Halfon and Zac Goldsmith have complained to party HQ, claiming that attending the 2014 conference was in itself a breach of the party's code of conduct and does nothing to combat the scourge of anti-Semitism. Quite the reverse.  Lord Sheikh was vocal last week in his criticism of Boris Johnson's comments comparing burqa-wearers to bank robbers and letterboxes.  And Mr Goldsmith has repeatedly refused to apologise over his 2016 run for Mayor of London, where he was accused of using dog whistle tactics to paint Sadiq Khan as extreme.   Lord Sheikh said the trip, paid for by the Tunisian Government, was properly declared, and he only attended part of it. He said: I was invited by the President of Tunisia to visit Tunis on 29 September – 2 October 2014. My trip was declared under the Parliamentary rules. I did state that the Government of Tunisia did pay for my flights and accommodation. The meeting was held in the context of the Arab Spring which affected the whole of the Middle East and North Africa. I arrived in the early hours and attended the conference which started at about 9:30 am. I only attended the morning session as I left the conference to rest as I was very tired. And he insisted he was not aware of the ceremony attended by Mr Corbyn where wreaths were laid next to memorials to several alleged members of Black September, who were behind the 1972 Munich Olympics massacre.  He said: At the conference, I saw Jeremy Corbyn. I was not aware and did not know that Jeremy Corbyn was going to be there. I did not meet with any members of Hamas. I did not know anything about the wreath laying ceremony. I was not told about this and did not attend the ceremony… Corbyn yesterday said the tribute he personally paid was in memory of a 1985 Israeli air raid on the PLO offices in the city - regardless of where in the cemetery the wreath was placed. Lord Sheikh added: I have a very good connection with the Jewish Peers and in fact I worked with Lord Palmer when the practice of Shechita and Halal meat was raised. We saw the relevant minister together and I spoke on this subject in the House of Lords. I have also looked at issues with the Jewish community relating to post-mortems and circumcision. At school, my best friend was a Jewish boy and I have connections with Jewish families.

Trying to sound like just another long-suffering commuter is the political equivalent of waving your arms around in panic. What a pathetic way to run a railway. title: ron stallworth explains how became
story: NewsRon Stallworth explains how he became first black member of the KKK - and even became head of local branchAhead of release of Spike Lee film BlacKkKlansman, undercover cop tells how he spent a year infiltrating the Ku Klux Klan and exposing their links with the police, military and organised crimeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByOliver Milne21:15, 15 AUG 2018Updated00:56, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTo his fellows in the Colorado Springs branch of the KKK , Ron Stallworth was in many ways the perfect Klansman. Always on time, well organised and, based on all the conversations the Ku Klux Klan’s members had with him, a powerful advocate for their hateful racist politics. What they didn’t know was that Ron was a black police officer. In 1979, Officer Stallworth, then 29, spent a year infiltrating the KKK and exposing their links with the police, military and organised crime. His audacious scheme, which started when he saw an advert in his local paper asking for potential KKK members, has inspired what some critics have called “the most important film of the year”, BlacKkKlansman. But in many ways, the truth is even stranger than Spike Lee’s movie makes it out to be. Working as an intelligence officer for the Colorado Springs Police Department, Ron was the only black officer on the force. So he took the rising tide of racist violence very seriously. And when he answered that advert, picking up the phone to talk to local KKK organiser Ken O’Dell, Ron knew he was risking more than embarrassment if they found out who he was.  America was gripped by far-right terrorism in the 1970s. In 1971, KKK members used dynamite to blow up ten buses which were to be used to desegregate schools in Pontiac, Michigan. In the months when Ron was planning his scheme, five communist protestors demonstrating in a Death To The Klan march were killed by the KKK and the American Nazi Party in the Greensboro massacre in North Carolina. In 1980, four black women were shot in Chattanooga, Tennessee, after a KKK rally. Just six months, later Michael Donald, age 20, was lynched in Alabama, his body found hanging from a tree. With this kind of bigoted violence going on, it’s fair to say that Ron knew the kind of character he was supposed to be playing when trying to ingratiate himself with the KKK’s O’Dell. Ron said: “I eventually spoke with him over the phone responding to that ad, and he explained to me that he was starting a Klan chapter in Colorado Springs and was looking for new people. “So I told him that I was a white man, that I hated blacks, Jews, Mexicans, Asians. That I thought the white man had not gotten a fair deal in this country. “[That] I was really upset because my sister had dated a n***** and it offended me that his black hands had touched her white body. And, as a result, I wanted to join the group and do what I could to put a stop to all of this nonsense.”  That was all it took – Ron, who now lives in El Paso, Texas, with his wife, was in. But very quickly he knew he was going to get caught if he couldn’t solve a major problem. How could he, a black man, walk into the public meetings of a large and violent racist organisation dedicated to seeing him back in chains? He was fine dealing with them over the phone, but he knew that when it came to having face-to-face meet-ups, he couldn’t go himself. So he drafted in his friend, Chuck, who worked in the drug squad, to be Ron Stallworth in person. It was also at this point that Ron realised he had – perhaps shortsightedly – signed his own name on his first letter to the KKK. However, it wasn’t just the practical problems holding up Ron’s investigation. Senior officers took a while to be convinced of its merits. “They felt like they couldn’t lose investigators to a bunch of nonsense like ‘men running around in sheets’,” said Ron. But with no signs of America’s racial violence subsiding, senior officers eventually agreed. Ron arranged to meet O’Dell, who was a serving soldier, at a bar near Fort Carson military base. He sent Chuck in wearing a wire, and guided him through the tricky conversations. “That’s how we conducted this investigation over the next eight or nine months or so,” Ron said. “I did most of the talking on the phone with these individuals, and when it came time for physical contact, the face-to-face meeting, I would send the white officer in posing as me.”  After months of phone calls and secret meetings, the infiltration was going so well that, incredibly, O’Dell recommended that Ron be made the head of the Colorado Springs branch of the KKK. He was put in touch with the hate group’s leader, David Duke. At one point – clearly confident that his plan hadn’t been rumbled – he even asked the KKK’s leader about the threat of infiltration. Ron explained: “I said, aren’t you afraid of an undercover police officer infiltrating your organisation or maybe a black man calling you up and pretending to be white?” “He said no, he wasn’t fearful of that at all, because he could always tell when he was talking to a black person.” Pushing his luck, Ron asked how Duke knew that he wasn’t black. “He said, you don’t talk like a black man. You talk like a very smart, intellectual white man. I can tell by the way you pronounce certain words.” Then, in an incident that seems more like far-fetched movie plot than real life, Ron – in his role as a serving police officer, rather than an undercover agent – met Duke in person. He was tasked with protecting the so-called Grand Wizard while he delivered a racist rant in public. He said: “I went and introduced myself to David Duke without giving him a name and told him I would do everything I could to protect him, even though I didn’t agree with him. We shook hands and I became his bodyguard.” Ron’s investigation in many ways highlighted his worst-possible fears. He found Klansmen in all walks of life, from local shop owners to school teachers and his neighbours.

story: NewsAmerican on Dublin honeymoon facing three attempted murder charges after pub brawlNicholas Keith Warner charged with attempting to murder three men, two of them aged in their 30s and one aged in his 60sShare&nbspByGeorge JacksonKelly-Ann Mills20:55, 15 AUG 2018Updated21:25, 15 AUG 2018NewsAmerican Nicholas Keith Warner is charged with three counts of attempted murderGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA recently married man, celebrating his honeymoon with his wife in Dublin, has appeared in court facing attempted murder charges. Nicholas Keith Warner, who arrived in Ireland last week, appeared at Limavady Magistrate’s Court charged with attempting to murder three men, two of them aged in their 30s and one aged in his 60s.  The three men each sustained stabbing injuries in an incident outside a bar at Main Street in the Co Antrim village of Ballycarry last Saturday night.  Warner, an electrical engineer from Morrow Lane in Summerville, South Carolina, denies attempting to murder the three men and he also denies assaulting a fourth man. The defendant further denies causing an affray but he admits possessing a knife.  The defendant, who sustained a broken leg in the incident, was helped by two police officers as he walked on crutches from a cell van on Main Street, Limavady, into the courthouse for his remand appearance. His wife Kaylee, a nurse also from South Carolina, sat behind her husband as he sat in the dock during the hearing. When asked by the court clerk if he understood the charges, the defendant replied “yes mam”. A detective constable told Deputy District Judge Ted Magill that he believed he could connect the defendant to the charges and he said alcohol was an issue in the case. Defence solicitor David Jones told the court that bail conditions proposed by the police and by the Public Prosecution Service were acceptable to the defendant.  “He accepts he was the individual who caused the injuries. From the moment of his arrest prior to his interviews he accepted he possessed the knife to defend himself”, Mr Jones said. “This case will come down to the argument of reasonable force or otherwise and because he is a US citizen I would request that if possible the case could be fast tracked. It is regrettable in that he is here on his honeymoon and his employment as an electrical engineer is now is jeopardy”, Mr Jones added. The defendant was released on his own bail of &pound1,000 to appear at Ballymena Magistrate’s Court on September 6.

story: NewsBest and worst schools in England and Wales revealed - is your child's on the list?The Real Schools Guide 2018 utilises a range of date from attendance to student progress in order to rank state-funded secondariesShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByClaire MillerElaine McCahill10:50, 15 AUG 2018Updated11:24, 15 AUG 2018NewsThe best and worst state-funded secondary schools in England and Wales have been revealed (Image: iStockphoto)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe best and worst state-funded secondary schools in England and Wales have been revealed. Using information compiled by 's data department, we can reveal the best and worst performing schools.  Wembley High Technology College in Brent, London is the top school in England, while Cockshut Hill Technology College, Birmingham, has ranked last.   In Wales, Bishop Of Llandaff Church In Wales High School in Cardiff tops the rankings.  This is the sixth edition of the Real Schools Guide which is the most comprehensive guide ever on state-funded secondaries. The unique rating system uses 51 different measures, put together from the latest publicly-available data and broken into four categories – attainment, teaching, attendance, and outcomes. While national league tables may only examine GCSE results, the Real Schools Guide looks at schools which help all students to make progress, even if they only get slightly better than average exam scores overall.   See below to search for your school   Even those that include the new Progress 8 measure may overlook schools helping all pupils do well. The ranking system aims to give parents a better idea of which schools will help their child prosper, no matter what their background may be. The guide shows interesting trends with 80 per cent of the top 20 schools in England based in London and the South East.  What do you think of your school's performance? Email webnews@mirror   Four our of the top five schools in England are based in London. Just four of the schools are from the north and midlands with two form Lancashire, and one each from Liverpool and Reading. As well as this, girls-only secondaries make up half of the top performing schools in England's top 20.    In Wales' top 20, a quarter of the top schools are based in Cardiff while 25 per cent of the worst secondaries are in Flintshire. The top two worst performing schools in Wales, Glyn Derw High School and Michaelston Community College, both in Cardiff, were closed last summer to make way for the new Cardiff West Community High School. Other factors are also included in the data such as whether all pupils are making progress, attendance rates, the ratio of teachers to pupils, school finances, and whether students go on to further education or jobs. Attainment is worth 30 per cent of the total score. This is based on pupils’ Attainment 8, EBacc and GCSE performance in 2017.   Whether a school is getting top marks and if its GCSE results are improving year-on-year is also measured. Progress is worth 40 per cent of the score and is based on how well all as well as different types of pupil do in comparison to expectations and how well the school does at closing the gender gap. It also looks at how big the pupil/teacher ratio is in comparison to the national average, as well as teachers’ average salaries. The attendance score is based on absence rates, looking at both overall levels of sessions missed as well as unauthorised and persistent absence at the school. It is worth 15 per cent of the total score. Outcomes is also worth 15 per cent, and is based on what proportion of pupils continue with education, employment or training after Year 11, and what proportion leave employment, education or training within three months - in comparison to the national average.  Schools that had no Year 11 pupils taking Attainment 8 qualifying subjects in 2017 are not rated.  Speaking about Wembley High Technology College topping the list, Cllr Amer Agha, Brent Council’s Cabinet Member for Schools, Employment and Skills, said:     “Our aim is to ensure that every child in Brent has the best start in life possible, and so having one of our schools recognised as the best in the country, is hugely satisfying and testament to the hard work that’s been put in by everyone at the school.        “Coming a month after the council’s best-ever Ofsted rating and a few months after a Brent teacher won the Global Teacher Prize, this is another great day for Brent’s young people and I offer my sincere thanks and congratulations to all those involved.” The unique rating system uses 50 different measures, put together from the latest publicly-available data and broken into four categories - attainment, progress, attendance, and outcomes. National league tables may only look at overall GCSE results, as well as newer measures. Attainment This is worth 30 per cent of the total score. It is based on pupils' average grade attainment score, including what the average scores for different groups of pupils were, as well as the proportions gaining the English Baccalaureate and those getting A* to C grades in GCSE subjects. It measures whether a school is getting top marks, and if it is managing to improve year-on-year. Progress This is worth 40 per cent of the score. It is based on how well different types of pupil do in terms of progressing. It also looks at things that may contribute to teaching outcomes, such as how big the pupil/teacher ratio is in comparison to the national average, as well as teachers' average salaries. Attendance This score is based on absence rates, looking at both overall levels of sessions missed as well as unauthorised and persistent absence at the school. It is worth 15 per cent of the total score. Outcomes This is also worth 15 per cent, and is based on what proportion of pupils continue with education after Year 11 or go on to training and work.

title: boy 5 completely traumatised after
story: NewsBoy, 5, "completely traumatised" after being repeatedly bitten by teenage girl in McDonald'sCharlie Vyse was pinned down in the middle of the fast food restaurant, while the stranger, believed to be 13-years-old, slapped and kicked himShare&nbspByYasmin HarishaKelly-Ann Mills17:24, 15 AUG 2018Updated23:11, 15 AUG 2018News (Image: SWNS- Cambridge)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA five-year-old boy has been left completely traumatised after being repeatedly bitten by a teenage girl in McDonald's. Charlie Vyse was pinned down in the middle of the fast food restaurant, while the stranger, believed to be 13-years-old, slapped and kicked him. The little boy suffered wounds to his legs, hands and arms as a result of the bloodied assault, which his mum Jessica believes could have killed a child. Jessica, 25, said: I was terrified. Hearing your child cry, because he was screaming... it was probably one of the worst things that I’ve ever been through. As a mum, it’s just so horrific. I can’t even imagine how much that hurt because her whole weight was on him pinning him down while she was biting him. It was horrific.  Jessica, Charlie and his little sister Elsie, two, were on their way back from a family day out when they stopped at the McDonald’s in Hampton near Peteborough, Cambs. He had been holding his mother's hand but she turned round after feeling his hand slip out of hers to see the girl on top of him. A woman, believed to be the girl's mum, was telling her to stop and allegedly said ‘I’m sorry, she’s autistic,’ according to the mother. Jessica said the girl was “hitting, scratching, biting. Down his back, his bottom, his legs.”  She said: I leaned down and I was saying ‘oh no, jump up’. As I got down to lift him up, I realised the girl was shaking her head and her teeth were in his back. He was obviously hysterical. “Charlie was still crying. I managed to pull him away slightly but it was at least 30 seconds, and she was biting him all the way down his body as I dragged him. “She was biting, hitting, scratching him. Then I fell back myself and had Charlie on top of me because I gave one last tug.”  The mum, who is a student children's nurse, pulled her children away to the disabled toilets where she found blood running down a tearful Charlie’s back. They then left McDonald’s, despite the girl allegedly trying to attack Charlie again, who was left “completely traumatised”. Jessica claims the police initially failed to investigate the incident which happened in July but have since made inquiries.  Jessica says Charlie is now receiving support and counselling due to the trauma caused. She said: Charlie is getting the support he needs and counselling from the relevant people, so hopefully we can move forward from this. I just think the whole thing has touched upon a subject that is clearly delicate but that needs addressing. Jessica shared a post about the experience on social media, which has since been shared more than 7,000 times.

title: british tourist who moaned benidorm
story: NewsBritish tourist who moaned Benidorm holiday was ruined 'by too many Spanish people' slammed by localsFreda Jackson, 81, said she cried at the end of her two-week trip and that the hotel her and a friend stayed at was "full of Spanish holidaymakers"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary20:29, 15 AUG 2018Updated20:31, 15 AUG 2018NewsFreda had visited the Benidorm hotel with a friend before being alarmed by the number of Spanish guests (Image: Lancashire  / SWNS)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British tourist who moaned her Benidorm holiday was ruined 'by too many Spanish people' has been slammed by locals. Freda Jackson, 81, said she cried at the end of her two-week trip and that the hotel she stayed in was full of Spanish holidaymakers. The grandmother, from Blackburn, Lancashire, went on to complain that the Spanish guests at the Poseidon Playa hotel were rude and that the evening entertainment was all focused and catered for the Spanish. Now, locals have hit back at the pensioner, saying she needs to scrub up on her geography skills next time she plans to take a trip abroad.  After the story appeared on Spanish news site Marca , one reader said: We should remind the good lady that Benidorm is in Spain.  Another said: If she hates Spain so much...why is she coming. It seems it would be good to learn some geography.  Freda had booked her Benidorm holiday in April 2017 after claiming travel operator Thomas Cook had recommended the hotel. But despite her request for ground access flat, Freda and her 61-year-old friend were placed on a slope instead. Grandmother-of-six Freda and her friend paid a total of &pound1,133 for the holiday and have demanded a full refund or a free trip. Freda said: I have never complained about a holiday before - but this one was a disaster from start to finish. She added: My friend and I paid for it from our pensions and it was a struggle trying to fund it over 12 months and the holiday was totally ruined - I cried after. The hotel was full of Spanish holidaymakers and they really got on our nerves because they were just so rude.  One evening a Spanish guy nearly knocked me flying and he just walked off without even apologising. The entertainment in the hotel was all focused and catered for the Spanish - why can't the Spanish go somewhere else for their holidays? Freda claims her requests for specific flats in the hotel were ignored and the operator failed to inform them of a change to the flights. She added: We wanted to go somewhere on flat ground and not in the hills because we have mobility issues. To top it off once we got to reception they told us we had been put on the 14th floor, thankfully we were moved to the second floor, and that it was 42 steps down to the hotel's swimming pool. The pair travelled 1,500 miles from Manchester Airport to Alicante on May 10, after not being notified by Thomas Cook that the dates of their flights had changed. Freda, who has previously visited Greece, Turkey, Portugal and Tenerife, claims Thomas Cook 'mis-sold' and 'ruined' her dream holiday.

title: dad who lost limbs electric
story: NewsDad who lost all limbs in electric shock splits from mum of his twins 'because he didn't want to be a burden'Scaffolder Jamie Mines, 34, suffered devastating injuries after being thrown 13ft from a half-finished metal roof when 33,000 volts of electricity surged through a tin sheet he was holdingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySarah LumleyElaine McCahill11:58, 15 AUG 2018NewsJamie Mines, who lost his limbs in a work accident, has split from his partner because he 'didn't want to be a burden' (Image: SWNS)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad who lost all his limbs in a electric shock has learned to look after himself and his twin girls after splitting from their mum - because he didn't want to be a burden.  Scaffolder Jamie Mines, 34, was thrown 13ft from a half-finished metal roof when 33,000 volts of electricity surged through a tin sheet he was holding.  The talented footballer spent ten weeks in intensive care supported by then-girlfriend Harley Ware and their twin daughters Savannah and Isabella. But Jamie has revealed he has now amicably split from 26-year-old Harley and is living alone and regularly looks after the kids. Despite his injuries the loving dad is thriving with his four prosthetic limbs, cleaning his home and cooking for himself and his daughters when they visit.  Jamie of Frome, Somerset, has claw hands on the ends of his prosthetic arms and says he lives for his visits from Savannah and Isabella. He can even clamber up on to the low trampoline in his back garden to bounce with them. Jamie has also learnt to drive thanks to a specially-adapted steering wheel fitted with a tetragrip lever, which accelerates when flicked up and reverses when flicked down. He is using the gym everyday, is eyeing a return to football, and is aiming to be a Paralympic runner. Jamie has been living on his own since February this year, after parting amicably from Harley.  She remained by his bedside while he was placed in an induced coma for three weeks at Southmead Hospital, Bristol following the incident in December 2016. Jamie said: We parted on good terms. I just didn't want to be a burden - she had to deal with a lot, looking after me. Now, Jamie sees adorable Savannah and Isabella once a week for a day and overnight, and has thrown himself into fatherhood. He said: I'm getting fitter each day. I take the girls to the park when they're here, or we'll go to Longleat safari park. They like being outdoors, which can be hard for me, because I get tired very quickly. But I've started going to the gym for an hour every morning, trying to get my energy levels back up to how they were before the accident.  Jamie has care staff visit twice a day, at 12pm and 6pm, to help him around the house - but he says he is able to do most things for himself. He said: I can cook for myself if it's something that just needs to go on a baking tray in the oven, and I can boil veg and so on. I can pretty much do most things for myself - I can hoover the house, but the one thing I struggle with is dusting. He added: I have dressed the girls before, but it takes me about an hour to do. So the carer helps me get them dressed and undressed, and helps with bathtimes and nappy changes and things like that. But, just like any other dad of toddlers, Jamie has no problems scooping Savannah and Isabella up in his arms, or putting them in their high-chairs and preparing an afternoon snack. And outside of caring for his girls once a week, Jamie id determined to get back into sport - and is working towards his ultimate goal of becoming a Paralympic runner.  He is awaiting the arrival of special running blade prosthetic legs to allow him to get back into one of his former favourite pasttimes. Jamie, who had his final limb, his left leg, removed on July 4 last year, said: I was up and about almost as soon as I had my second prosthetic leg fitted on August 20. I took to it straight away. I was a bit wobbly at first, but it only took me an hour so to get used to it. The mind is your only barrier. A lot of people who need amputations in adulthood are quite scared of adapting to losing a limb. But I wasn't scared or anything. The determined former football striker now spends an hour each morning at the gym - and says he can use almost all the equipment, except the machine weights. I do 20 minutes cycling, and I also work out my shoulders, chest and back, said Jamie.

title: farmer puts 30ft wall hay
story: NewsFarmer puts 30ft-wall of hay outside neighbours' homes - but denies that he's a "bully"Residents have accused the farmer of "bullying" after the bales were heaped outside their homes in DerbyshireShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByArun Lal19:06, 15 AUG 2018NewsPeter Shaw, 55 and wife Helen, 50, are furious after the hay bales suddenly appeared (Image: SWNS)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA farmer has denied that he is a bully after 30ft-high stacks of hay were placed outside his wealthy neighbours' homes. The massive stack of hay has been piled up on trailers in a field adjacent to the back gardens of several &pound500,000 detached properties. Villagers believe they were put there deliberately after a planning application by farmer Richard Barton to run a waste processing site was rejected. But Mr Barton has defended the move, accusing neighbours of making a straw mountain out of a molehill. Among those affected was resident Peter Shaw, 55, who said the bales were stacked behind his house on Cole Road, Ockbrook, Derbyshire, last Thursday.  Mr Shaw and his wife Helen, 50, moved into the home in 2004, and say this is the first time they have encountered an issue with Mr Barton. Mr Shaw, who works in the motoring trade, says the bales are a potential fire risk and is urging Mr Barton, 44, to remove them. He said: The farmer won't speak to you, I have tried. He's just a bully. I truly believe it is just something we are going to have to live with now. I have contacted everyone and anyone that I possibly can and nothing seems to getting done about it.  It feels as though there is one rule for one person and another rule for others. It's an eye sore - I'm not sure they are even stored correctly. He's put 30 tons on a trailer. First, the lorries came and they were full of hay bales and he put them in place one by one. So we've got three in a row. More and more bales were put on top - there might be a row of seven or eight - I'm not entirely sure now. You can see it from the road, you can see it from the footbridge.  It's about ten meters from my home - if they were to fall then they would destroy my garden. I thought they were a fire risk but the fire brigade said to me they're not a fire risk. The farmer has been trying to put a planning application through now for the past eight years. He wants to create a site to process waste. The application has been rejected not just by ourselves but by the whole village. It just seems because my house backs onto his farm - that we have to bear the brunt of this. Another resident on the street said: The view from our back garden used to be open fields but now all you can see is a wall of hay.  I'm convinced this is some kind of protest against the village because the farmer didn't get the planning permission he wanted. It's a form of intimidation and is just simply being done out of spite. Speaking from his farm in Ockbrook, Derbys., where he lives with wife Samantha, 50, he said: It's got nothing to do with the planning application for a waste processing site. Where am I supposed to put my bales? They [the residents] are selfish - all they think about is themselves. All they want to see is green land but I don't even get that view and its my farm. I've got my property here, I can't put them [hay bales] on my drive because there's no space - I've got sheds in the way too. There's a dual carriageway on the other side I can't put them there. He added: They're making a straw mountain out of a molehill. I put them in the middle of the field and they complained about that and the council told me to move them. Now I've moved them they're complaining again. All they've done for the past few years is try and portray me as some horrible neighbour and horrible person. It's not their fields - I live literally next to the bales too. The fire brigade have come out and said it's not a fire risk. I don't know why they called me a bully - I'm not a bully. I've lived here my whole life - my mum and dad have lived here too - we've always farmed. I've never not farmed and they're telling the council I don't farm.

story: NewsFather who took Viagra fractured PENIS after child jumped on bed trying to wake him upAccording to the British Medical Journal, the man expected its effects to have worn off after sex, but instead it remained working until the following morningShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary19:22, 15 AUG 2018Updated20:13, 15 AUG 2018NewsThe man reported to hospital two days after suffering a painful tear (Image: E+)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father who took Viagra fractured his penis after his child 'fell over' his erection while jumping on him to wake him up. The 36-year-old, who has not been named, had taken Viagra the night before the accident.  According to the British Medical Journal , the man expected its effects to have worn off after sex, but resorted to 'vigorous masturbation' when it failed to do so.  The following morning, the Viagra was continuing to work, before his child jumped on the bed in an attempt to wake him, but 'mistakenly fell over his erect penis', according to King George’s Medical University.  The journal goes on to explain how the man, from India, developed 'sudden severe pain in his penis and lost tumescence' - the build up of blood. After two days in agonising pain, he reported himself to doctors who confirmed a tear in his corpora cavernosa - the tissue that stores blood during an erection. His penis was said to be deformed and swollen from the injury.

title: how pals woman 31 who
story: NewsHow friends of woman, 31, who woke up screaming seven times in 'barbaric' death are fulfilling her last wishEXCLUSIVE: Fiona Strong, 31, suffered a "barbaric" death as she repeatedly woke up screaming from a drug-induced 'final sleep' - now her two best pals are fulfilling her final wishShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans15:26, 15 AUG 2018Updated15:45, 15 AUG 2018NewsFiona Strong, pictured with best pals Abbie and Sally, passed away on May 1 this year (Image: Mirrorpix)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave young woman who woke up screaming seven times as she died from cancer will have her selfless final wish granted - thanks to her best pals. Terminally-ill Fiona Strong suffered a barbaric death as she repeatedly came out of a drug-induced sleep from which she had never expected to awake. Confused and scared, the 31-year-old spent her last days in agonising pain - with her heartbroken loved ones forced to say goodbye again and again. She had wanted to die with dignity - a wish she didn't get. But now, her close pals Sally Johnstone and Abbie Haggan are making sure another of her wishes is fulfilled - to help homeless and disadvantaged people. The grieving friends will be cycling nearly 1,000 miles from Land's End, Cornwall, to John O'Groats, Scotland, to raise money for a fund in Fiona's name. They start their challenge this weekend - and they can't wait.   We’re really looking forward to it and hope we achieve something that would have made Fi very proud, Sally and Abbie told . We have known Fi since we were 11. Everyone brings their own individual element to a friendship and Fiona's was energy, humour and charm to what some would say is our slightly more prudish and reserved selves. We used to talk about how lucky we were as a group that nothing bad had ever happened to us – we are privileged, especially with having wonderfully loving family and friends. When Fi got sick she would often reflect on this. It felt like our amazing good fortune might have run out. The pair had last seen Fiona at The Margaret Centre at Whipps Cross Hospital, east London, on Thursday, April 26, just days before she took her final breaths. They had initially planned to start their bike ride that Sunday, but when their friend's condition deteriorated, they secretly postponed it to be close to her. They decided not to tell her, knowing she would be upset with the postponement because of the amount of time and planning they had put into the challenge. Abbie and Sally will start their LEJOG challenge on Sunday. Fiona's mum Susan said: They have been and continue to be wonderful to Fiona. It would have been so easy to just cancel the challenge after Fiona died but they are determined to carry on. They have certainly gone above and beyond the realms of friendship for Fiona. Here is the pair's itinerary for their bike ride: August 19 - Land's End to Camelford August 20 - Camelford to Tiverton August 21 - Tiverton - Clevedon August 22 - Clevedon - Tewkesbury August 23 - Tewkesbury - Stafford August 24 - Stafford - Hindley August 25 - Hindley - Kendal August 26 - Kendal - Lockerbie August 27 - Lockerbie to Newbridge (Edinburgh) August 28 - Newbridge to Pitlochry August 29 - Pitlochry - Craggie August 30 - Craggie - Golspie August 31 - Golspie to Inverness To donate to Abbie and Sally's cause, click here. Every time a nurse walked into the room, she [Fiona] said, 'This is Sally and Abbie who are cycling 1000 miles!',  the friends recalled. There was no way we could tell her we might not be leaving for the ride, especially if she thought it had anything to do with her, so we decided to give her a cuddle before we set off and give her a chance to wish us luck. They added: We both held her hands - Fi liked to hold your hand - and chatted about the ridiculous challenge ahead. We gave her a kiss and said 'love you' - which we always say now as friends - and left her be. The following day, Abbie and Sally received the heartwrenching news that Fiona wouldn't be able to take part in an immunotherapy trial she had hoped for. They were told she would soon die, with her cancer quickly growing. We took the decision not to go and see Fiona again as she was very content in the knowledge that we had set off on the cycle and we wanted it to stay that way, said the friends, who were taking unpaid leave from work for the ride. She would have been furious if she thought we’d postponed because of her.  They added: She asked her friend Mel who was at the hospice throughout to send us a message from Fi’s phone on the Saturday, which read ‘Hey gang. Wishing you an awesome start on this exciting adventure. 'I’m behind you every pedal of the way. Love loads xxxx’. We believe she is. Fiona, who first met Abbie and Sally at secondary school, had been diagnosed with the rare and aggressive childhood cancer rhabdomyosarcoma in 2015. As the disease progressed, it snatched away her ability to move, eat or drink. But the stoic young woman was determined to not be a vegetable, telling her mum Susan Strong earlier this year: I really want to die with dignity. In her last days, she courageously opted for medication to relieve her overwhelming pain that she knew, as a side effect, would result in sedation. She then shared a final, emotional goodbye with Susan in her hospice room. But as we reported in June, instead 'sleeping' peacefully until she passed away, as hoped, Fiona woke up in terrible pain just 20 minutes later.  And for the next four days, she continued to wake. Terrified, she would scream out in pain as her loved ones and doting nurses tried to comfort her. Each time, Susan would say another 'last goodbye' to her daughter, who had told medics she did not want to be fed or watered while receiving end-of-life care. But it was only after seven farewells that Fiona eventually died on May 1. Her mum has since been campaigning for assisted dying - and has insisted she would have helped her daughter to end her own life, if possible. We must have said our goodbyes six or seven times until she finally passed away, said Susan, who described Fiona's treatment as 'terminal sedation'. She underwent five days of continual waking and pain. Every time she fell asleep, we thought that would be it. It would be very upsetting - then she'd wake up again. At one point, she woke up and was thirsty. I gave her a drink and she said. 'Mum, stop trying to keep me alive.' It was scary for her as well. It's not what she wanted. It was torturous. Fiona's mum Susan said her daughter loved animals, scuba diving and conservation. She also used to work with children with disabilities, which she adored.  The Fiona Strong Memorial Fund has been set up in her name.  With this foundation she will be able to help an eclectic group of people, individuals and organisations who champion the plight of the homeless for example, Susan said. The Foundation is being set up through the Community Foundation for Surrey. Fiona worked at the Safeguarding Children department at Surrey Council and she was very keen to also help children who were either abused or disadvantaged.  This charity receive requests for grants and distribute the funds to those in need with the authority of Fiona's brother, Iain who is overseeing the foundation. Speaking to  earlier this summer, she added: It was more difficult [for Fiona] because she was having to say goodbyes to everybody again and again and again. There was no peace of mind. Even the nurses and doctors at the hospice were in distress as there was nothing further they could do to ease her suffering. Continuous deep sedation, often labelled 'terminal sedation' or 'palliative sedation' by relatives, has been used for decades to relieve the suffering of the terminally ill. The hospice says while it increased Fiona's sedation to relieve her agitation as safely as it could, she did experience some consciousness in her final days. Although the young woman was not given food or liquid at this time, in accordance with her wishes, her mouth and lips were kept moist by hospice nurses. She was also given medication to relieve her unbearable pain. But despite medics' best efforts to care for her at the facility in Leytonstone, they could not stop her excruciating suffering - because of the law, her mum said.  [The doctors] didn't use the words 'terminal sedation' said Susan, who was joined at the hospice by Fiona's dad, Clive Strong, and devoted boyfriend, Alex Paxton. She claimed: They said to Fi, 'We could sedate you and you wouldn't wake up after about four hours and eventually just stay asleep.' The mum-of-two, 61, is fighting for compassionate euthanasia in a bid to prevent hundreds of others from going through the same ordeal Fiona did. If she was well enough I'd have taken her to Dignitas in Switzerland, she said. She was screaming out all the time, even with all that pain relief. It was just awful. All she wanted to do was keep her dignity in tact and be pain-free. We would not allow an animal to suffer like this. She added: Fiona was so stoic and brave but how she died was so unnecessary. Abbie and Sally agreed, telling : We passionately support the call for compassionate euthanasia. What Fiona went through in her final days was barbaric and her family and friends will have to live with that forever.  Seeing our brave friend sobbing because she wasn’t able to stay still long enough for a scan because she was in agony but couldn’t have more pain relief will forever haunt us. They added: One of the main arguments against it is the belief that palliative care should be improved - we cannot speak more highly of the palliative care team that looked after Fiona. They were wonderful and did everything they could possibly do to make her more comfortable within the constraints of the law – their job is to make the unbearable a bit more bearable for everyone affected and they did that. They too were distressed at the point that they could not do any more. Assisted dying is illegal in the UK, but a Mirror poll in June found that three out of four Brits would support a law change to allow it. They want people with a terminal illness who have six months or less to live to be given the right to decide when they die.  Abbie and Sally continued: No family or friend should ever be in the position where they are having to choose between denying their terminally-ill loved one their wish to die, when nothing more can be done to help them, and breaking the law or forcing them to take their own life. The law has to change. Fiona was diagnosed with rhabdomyosarcoma - a type of soft tissue sarcoma - in October 2015 after complaining of headaches, a numb face and nausea. But despite her worrying symptoms, it was only after her eye began protruding that a tumour was discovered in her paranasal sinuses. They told her it was a tumour and to prepare for cancer, Susan added. They had to do a biopsy to test whether it was the disease. After undergoing a biopsy at St George's Hospital in Tooting, south London, Fiona, then 28, returned to her Leytonstone home, where she was constantly sick. It was the tumour pressing on her brain causing her to be sick, her mum explained. We didn't sleep all night. As the sickness grew worse, Fiona ended up being admitted to hospital, where she was later told the news she and her family had feared.  The consultant came in and said, 'Unfortunately, it's a very rare type of cancer. It usually affects children but is very unusual in adults', Susan said. I was in bits, I was devastated. Fiona, who worked for a market research company, was told the tumour was in an awkward position, located in the bone and sinus behind her right eye. For the next 14 months, she underwent treatment at The Royal Marsden Hospital in Chelsea, including gruelling rounds of chemotherapy and radiotherapy. She suffered facial paralysis and spent her 29th birthday in intensive care battling sepsis - but faced it all with humour, dignity and incredible courage. Fiona gave the disease the respect it deserved but she didnt let it define her. She didn't want to be the person who was talking about her illness, Susan said. Despite her own struggles, Fiona also went out of her way to help others, raising more than &pound10,000 for cancer charities and donating her brunette hair to the Little Princess Trust. And in January 2017, she was given something she had dreamed of - the all-clear.  But tragically, after only four months of remission, her eye started playing up again and doctors told her that a new cancerous tumour had been found. Despite undergoing further chemotherapy, radiotherapy, a clinical trial and even surgery to remove her eye at Moorfields Eye Hospital, the disease spread. Before long, Fiona's tumour had invaded both her brain and her nose, making it difficult for her to breathe - with the cancer also in her neck, shoulder and spine. A nurse was coming to the house to give her pain relief, Susan said. They said, 'I think we should get her to a hospice'. In constant pain, Fiona was admitted to The Margaret Centre on April 9, where she was joined by mostly elderly patients and a team of compassionate nurses. She was on so many drugs, but they still couldn't control the pain, Susan said. She said to me, 'I'm going to give it till April 27. If I don't feel any better, I want you to help me end my life. Take me to Switzerland or something'. Before her admission, Fiona's loved ones had begun raising more than &pound100,000 for immunotherapy treatment which would have started later that month.  They raised a whopping &pound43,000 of their target, and despite her rapidly deteriorating condition, the young woman vowed to give it one last shot. Fiona said, 'even if immunotherapy gives me a few weeks extra', Susan said. She had a network of friends who were absolutely incredible. But unfortunately, Fiona, who loved scuba diving, travelling and socialising with pals, never got the chance to undergo immunotherapy. To her and her family's horror, her cancer was growing too fast. She had lost all mobility in her legs, couldn't walk, could partially move her neck... the tumour was growing so much it had grown into her neck, her mum said. Her tongue was swollen so she was finding it difficult to speak and eat. In late April, doctors asked Fiona what she wanted to happen. She said, 'I really want to die with dignity', I don't want to be a vegetable where I can't speak. I can't move and I've got no quality of life,' Susan said.  Fiona was told she could undergo end-of-life treatment to relieve her distress which, as a side effect, would cause her to fall into a 'deep sleep', according to her mum. She said that's what she wanted, she said. The young woman agreed to the treatment - involving syringe drivers and no food or water - which she hoped would leave her sedated until her eventual death. We all sat around her bed and said our goodbyes. We thought that that was going to be it. But it never happened... she kept waking up, Susan said. In some ways it was alarming because we were pleased she'd woken up selfishlessly. It was like a rollercoaster. She claimed that even the doctors and nurses were left stunned. Fiona would say something poignant about us all, it was quite distressing, said Susan, who is divorced from her daughter's dad and now with partner Steve, 62. We'd think 'well that's it'. And then she'd wake up. The nurses were in tears. In her final hours, Fiona's breathing became laboured and she started suffering from blood clots in her mouth, which caused her to gurgle.  The nurses had to use a suction pump to take them out, her mum said. She added: She then started making a noise as if she was calling me but couldn't speak. I got up and held her hand. She couldn't talk but she was aware I was there. The nurse said her breathing was getting shallower. Soon after, the young woman took her last breaths. She finally passed away on the Tuesday morning, said Susan, who moved down South from her home in Fife, Scotland, to care for Fiona. At the end of the day I didn't want to lose Fiona,but I didn't want her to be in pain. She definitely should've been allowed to end her own life. It wasn't what we imagined at all. Addressing concerns about relaxing euthanasia rules, the mum said she believes patients should have to sign a detailed document about their treatment.  We shouldn't be a passive patient, said Susan, who is staying at a friend's house, as she sorts out Fiona's belongings and flat. You'd have to be aware of what you were getting, it would need to be open. There could even be a medical card, like there has been with organ donation. She added:Fiona's quality of life had diminished drastically by the end. There does have to be a degree of dignity. We can keep people alive but it's wrong to keep them alive if they are suffering things so great. I wouldn't want my worst enemy to go through what Fiona went through. Critics have said relaxing assisted dying laws would put pressure on vulnerable people to end their lives out of fear of being a financial, emotional and care burden. However, campaign organisation Dignity in Dying says terminally ill adults such as Fiona should have the right to die on their own terms. A spokesman told the Mirror: “Nobody deserves to die in pain, suffering and without dignity. For most people, palliative care is excellent and will be able to give the vast majority of us a good death.  But for some people, like Fiona, even the very best care cannot prevent them having a bad death. We believe that dying people should be given the option of having an assisted death if they want to take control in their final days and have the good ending they deserve. The Margaret Centre is a specialist palliative care unit that provides care and support for people affected by life-limiting illnesses like cancer. Barts Health NHS Trust offered its deepest condolences to Fiona's family. A spokeswoman told  in June: This was a very sad case and we offer our deepest condolences to Ms Strong’s family. Ms Strong attended The Margaret Centre to relieve agitation she was experiencing as a result of her serious illness. Although we increased Ms Strong’s sedation to relieve agitation as safely as we could she did experience some consciousness in her final days.  Our priority is always to relieve any distress to patients throughout their illness and at the end of their life, and we will always strive to involve patients and their families in deciding the appropriate medication to meet their needs. Fiona was laid to rest in a scuba diving-themed coffin in May. Her guests celebrated her inspirational life with champagne and laughter. She wanted to be cremated, said Susan.  She said wherever we travel in the world, to sprinkle a bit of her. She said she felt she still had one long holiday left in her. She just enjoyed life. Abbie and Sally had initially aimed to raise awareness and funds for research into sarcoma , which has devastated too many lives, with their bike ride. They also wanted to give Fiona something to focus on and laugh at. But since her death, the challenge, dubbed 'LEJOG', has become something much more special and symbolic to us personally and those that knew her. It is a time to raise money, awareness and also to reflect on having had such a great friend in our life and a reminder to embrace the time we have in this world, the pals said. They are raising money for the Fiona Strong Memorial Fund, which was recently set up to provide vital support to those in need in Surrey. The fund aims to award grants to local non-profit organisations who provide support to the homeless, disadvantaged people and their relatives. And it will do so in Fiona's loving memory.

story: NewsMeghan Markle could be pregnant if you notice this sign - here's what to look forAlthough the Duchess hasn't announced a pregnancy, eagle-eyed observers think these subtle signs will reveal that she isShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRobyn Darbyshire19:11, 15 AUG 2018Updated23:08, 15 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRoyal fans across the world anxiously await the news that Meghan Markle is expecting a baby. story: NewsMeghan Markle's dad Thomas 'bitter' his children haven't given him a 'f***ing dime' since he retiredEXCLUSIVE The ex-Hollywood lighting director has told pals he expected Meghan, Samantha and Thomas Jr to help pay for his retirement but complained he had not received a “f***ing dimeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChristopher Bucktin22:14, 15 AUG 2018Updated23:38, 15 AUG 2018NewsThomas Markle has already said he expected Meghan to look after him (Image: TIM STEWART NEWS LIMITED)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThomas Markle is said to be &shygrowing “increasingly bitter” that his past generosity to his children has not been paid back. title: mum who paid exclusive dating
story: NewsMum who paid 'exclusive' dating agency £12,600 to find rich boyfriend gets money back after court orderA top judge ordered Seventy Thirty Ltd return the fee to Tereza Burki, 47, after it was unable to find her 'possibly the man of my dreams, the father of my child', she told the High CourtShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJames Brewster13:54, 15 AUG 2018Updated15:09, 15 AUG 2018NewsTereza Burki paid £12,600 to dating agency Seventy Thirty Ltd to find her 'the man of her dreams'Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA divorced mum-of-three who paid &pound12,600 to an exclusive dating agency is set to get her money back after it failed to find her a rich boyfriend . A top judge ordered Seventy Thirty Ltd return the fee to Tereza Burki, 47, after it was unable to find her 'the man of her dreams and possibly the father of her child', she told the High Court. She said the agency assured her it only dealt in creme de la creme matches and could introduce her to bachelors you dream of meeting. When she signed up with the agency in 2014, Ms Burki's requirements for the men she wanted to meet were not modest, Judge Richard Parkes QC said. She wanted a wealthy man with a lifestyle similar or more affluent than her own and, ideally, multiple residences. But the most important factor for Ms Burki, who lives in Lennox Gardens, Chelsea, where homes sell for millions, was that her soulmate would be prepared to have more children, as she wanted four.  But today Mr Parkes ordered the agency to repay her fee, ruling that she had been deceived by Seventy Thirty's then managing director. He told the court: Gertrude Stein quipped that whoever said money can't buy happiness didn't know where to shop. This case is about a woman looking for romantic happiness who says she was tricked into shopping in the wrong place, paying a large sum to a dating which, she says, made promises but failed to produce the goods. Upholding Ms Burki's claim , he ruled the agency's then managing director, Lemarc Thomas, guilty of deceit in misleading her. Although the agency boasted of more than 7,000 members, the truth was that only about 100 of them were men actively looking for love, he said. And the management consultant would never have paid her money and joined up had Mr Thomas not knowingly given her a wholly false impression.  Agency founder, Susie Ambrose, said Seventy Thirty had successfully matched over 6,000 lonely hearts and 63 babies had been born since she set it up in 2011. But the judge said Mr Thomas had told Ms Burki that there were a substantial number of wealthy men on the agency's books, actively looking for matches. She had no means of checking the truth of what he told her, and no reason to doubt it, he added. And she relied on Mr Thomas's word before spending a large amount of money on a dating agency in the hope of finding a partner who would give her a fourth child. The Knightsbridge-based agency claimed to have about 1,500 active members and that Ms Burki had been sent five potential matches that fit her requirements soon after joining. But the judge said: My conclusion from the evidence is that there are at the very most perhaps 200 active members of Seventy Thirty, and probably fewer. That points to a maximum of around 100 active male members.

title: uk weather forecast temperatures drop
story: NewsUK weather forecast: Temperatures to plunge as gulf stream shift brings heavy rain and strong windsThe Met Office has warned that Britain could see a sweeping of heavy showers and strong winds from tonight until at least the weekendShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop14:57, 15 AUG 2018Updated15:22, 15 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTemperatures will plummet this week as the gulf stream shifts across the UK, bringing an end to Britain's monster heatwave, forecasters warned. The current change in the jet stream’s direction will allow low pressure to become dominant for a few days before higher pressure returns and the weather system alters course again. The mercury will drop as low as 13C in Scotland and the north east over the next few days - coming only weeks after scorching temperatures of 35C were seen across large parts of the country. The Met Office warned that Britain could see a sweeping of heavy showers and strong winds from tonight until at least the weekend. Today the east of England and Scotland have been battered by thunderstorms and some torrential downpours - but they are set to move south wards as the week goes on.  We've got some unsettled weather continuing for the next few days, the Met Office's Luke Miall said. Quite a contrast really to what much of this summer has seen across the UK. The Met Office said rain that has been battering Scotland, northern England and northwest Wales will continue to push southeastwards tonight bringing heavy outbreaks for most of the country. Tomorrow there will be rain across parts of England and Wales, with sunny spells.  There will be some scattered, possibly thundery, showers in the north and west. Over the weekend it will be cloudy and windy with patches of heavy rain for the north and west of the country. It will be drier and brighter in the south and east but there is also potential for scattered showers. Waves or ripples along the jet stream can force Atlantic depressions to deepen violently as they are driven towards the UK, so they play a very important part in forecasting.

story: NewsLittle girl is swallowed whole by bouncy castle as she falls into near invisible gapHer brave mum and aunt plunged down the two metre deep hole in a desperate attempt to drag her outShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills20:00, 15 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA little girl is lucky to be alive after she fell inside a huge bouncy castle.
